Explanation: " Clues in the letter shows it is a fake (for instance, the signature) and Jean-Michel Blanquer, minister of Education, denied on Twitter publishing such a letter. He also denied any change in the holidays' schedule."

What did you fact-check?: Sophie Trudeau is sharing her COVID-19 experience.
Explanation: Video is of a woman from London and not Sophie Trudeau.

What did you fact-check?: A positive COVID-19 patient recently met Narendra Modi.
Explanation: A 2018 picture is being shared with a false narrative.

What did you fact-check?: A line of coffins suggesting they are from Italy currently.
Explanation: This image from 2013 shows migrants dying in a shipwreck.

What did you fact-check?: Cow urine is helpful to fight coronavirus.
Explanation: No scientific evidence backs the use of cow urine to fight viruses.

What did you fact-check?: The Colombian government just made it official that all citizens will receive 350,000 pesos a week for staying home to prevent the proliferation” of COVID-19.
Explanation: It is false that the Colombian government is giving 350,000 pesos to stay at home.

What did you fact-check?: Banglore Municipal body (BBMP) will be spraying medicine in the air to kill coronavirus.
Explanation: The BBMP Commissioner, the mayor and PIB Fact Check India have clarified that the viral message is a rumor and the BBMP has no such plans to spray medicine for COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: Sick COVID-19 patients at the airport runway in Senegal.
Explanation: Video is old and not from Italy. It actually shows a  mock drill carried out on 11/28/19 at Blaise Diagne Airport in Dakar, the capital of Senegal. It has nothing to do with coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Image claims that dead bodies from Italy are kept in a room.
Explanation: The image is from a Cairo Mosque which was turned into a makeshift morgue in 2013.

What did you fact-check?: Consuming alcoholic beverages may help reduce the risk of infection by the novel coronavirus.
Explanation: Drinking alcohol does not protect you from coronavirus infection, according to the WHO.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus will be cured after a 14-hour curfew.
Explanation: The novel coronavirus has different life spans on different objects. However, it can live up to 2 to 3 days.

What did you fact-check?: Bitter gourd juice can cure coronavirus.
Explanation: Bitter gourd juice cannot cure coronavirus. There is no cure for coronavirus as of this date.

What did you fact-check?: “Only India can resist coronavirus” — Saudi Crown Prince Mohammad Bin Salman.
Explanation: Saudi Crown Prince Mohammad Bin Salman has not made any such statement.

What did you fact-check?: Bill Gates and the Vatican have a plan to depopulate the world with a coronavirus vaccine.
Explanation: Video clip is taken out of context from a 2010 Gates TedTalk.

What did you fact-check?: US Homeland Security mobilizing National Guard to combat coronavirus.
Explanation: National Guard refuted claims.

What did you fact-check?: Joe Biden tested positive for coronavirus.
Explanation: Another news publication refuted the false claim.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus cases linked to 5G rollout.
Explanation: Overlaps in the map between 5G and cases can be explained by population density.

What did you fact-check?: Photo shows coffins from coronavirus outbreak in Italy.
Explanation: It is an old photo of African migrants who died in a shipwreck in 2013.

What did you fact-check?: Elderly COVID-19 patients won’t have access to respirators
Explanation: Several hospitals reached out by Maldita denied the claim.

What did you fact-check?: Seeing the rise of novel coronavirus in India, the WHO has recommended the government of India lockdown the country from 4/15/20 to 6/15/20.
Explanation: We reached out to one of the representatives in India, who dismissed the claim and clarified that WHO has not made any such recommendation.

What did you fact-check?: A WhatsApp video claims that the lady shown is the wife of Canada’s PM Justin Trudeau. In the viral video, a lady can be seen describing her improved condition because of medication and also warns to not take chances.
Explanation: The lady in the viral video is not Canadian PM Justin Trudeau’s wife Sophie Grégoire Trudeau but a British national named Tara Jane Langston.

What did you fact-check?: The King of Spain has plagiarized his COVID-19 speech from a book.
Explanation: " A picture shows a fragment of the King's speech and the image of a book as if the king had plagiarized his words from a writer."

What did you fact-check?: The schools in Bizkaia in Spain do not close until September.
Explanation: The Education ministry of The Basque Country denies this claim to Newtral.es.

What did you fact-check?: A video posted on Twitter shows a group of Chinese people converting to Islam under the argument that Muslims are immune to COVID-19.
Explanation: The claim is false. Islamic people are not immune to COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: Doctors are giving out “rescue packs” for people with pre-existing respiratory conditions.
Explanation: There is no evidence that doctors in Ireland are giving out packs containing steroids and antibiotics to people with pre-existing respiratory conditions, such as asthma or COPD. On the contrary, doctors have advised that such a move would not be safe, given the different needs that each patient would have.

What did you fact-check?: “If you are in Las Vegas and you get a knock on your door from NV Power, 2020 Census or CVD-19 testers, do not open your door. They are robbing people at gunpoint.”
Explanation: Las Vegas police said they have received no such reports. Similar rumors are being spread around the country.

What did you fact-check?: If people violate the quarantine measures in Ukraine, they will be imprisoned.
Explanation: According to the law on coronavirus in Ukraine, there is no such measure.

What did you fact-check?: Pets can transmit the new coronavirus.
Explanation: The is no proof that pets can transmit the new coronavirus, although the droplets with the virus can stay on pets and, then, get into the human organism.

What did you fact-check?: Pets can transmit the new coronavirus.
Explanation: The is no proof that pets can transmit the new coronavirus, although the droplets with the virus can stay on pets and, then, get into the human organism.

What did you fact-check?: Fill out a 2020 U.S. Census form to receive an economic stimulus payment.
Explanation: U.S. government payments for coronavirus relief will be determined by tax returns, not Census information.

What did you fact-check?: Rinsing throat and nose with warm and salt water will prevent the new coronavirus.
Explanation: Rinsing the throat and washing the nose with salty water may slightly alleviate a cold. However, it does not help with respiratory diseases, including COVID-19. The effectiveness of such treatment or prevention of the new coronavirus is not proven.

What did you fact-check?: A photo circulating on Facebook in Nigeria appears to show President Muhammadu Buhari shaking hands with the nation’s Code of Conduct Bureau Chairman Mohammed Isa while both men are wearing face masks — seemingly against precautions during the novel coronavirus pandemic.
Explanation: The image was doctored using an old photo, taken long before the pandemic.

What did you fact-check?: The death of Kobe Bryant overshadowed the news that an American drugmaker was hustling to make a vaccine for coronavirus, and 200 people died of COVID-19 in August 2019 in the USA.
Explanation: " An article about American drugmakers working on a new vaccine to counter the rapidly spreading respiratory virus was published in the American daily newspaper, USA Today, on 1/24/20. But it didn't mention a death toll of 200 in August 2019."

What did you fact-check?: Worshipers were beaten by policemen because they gathered in a church.
Explanation: We found the same video published on Twitter in November 2019, so before the outbreak of coronavirus. The caption was "Zimbabwe riot police attacked opposition party MDC Alliance supporters today who had gathered to hear leader, Nelson Chamisa, give his Hope of the Nation Address." Other pictures on Twitter and within AFP archives allow us to match the video with this anti riot police operation.

What did you fact-check?: A Chinese woman in Mombasa was attacked and killed after showing flu-like symptoms and refusing to go to hospital.
Explanation: The article uses an image from the 2013 Westgate terror attack in Kenya, and police in the area also had not received any information about the attack.

What did you fact-check?: 22 travelers in Uganda for the EU-Uganda Business Summit scheduled for early March had refused to go into quarantine.
Explanation: The 22 travelers had refused to go into quarantine and opted to travel back to their home countries, but they were not in Uganda for the conference as claimed.

What did you fact-check?: It is recommended to disinfect everything you buy with bleach to prevent infection from the coronavirus.
Explanation: It is not recommended. Experts say it is better to focus on washing your hands and to follow the official recommendations.

What did you fact-check?: Chloroquine could cure coronavirus.
Explanation: There is not enough conclusive evidence to point out chloroquine as a cure treatment.

What did you fact-check?: Stocks of “medical masks” made in Woippy, in Moselle, by a company are being blocked for lack of “agreement of the government,” in spite of a shortage of masks in France.
Explanation: Facebook users did not answer to AFP. Their publications mention a place that does not exist. The Woippy mayor told AFP he does not know about a company that is making masks in his city.

What did you fact-check?: Quotes Joe Biden as saying “people who have never died before are now dying from coronavirus.”
Explanation: " The quote was first misattributed to President Donald Trump. Joe Biden didn't say it either."

What did you fact-check?: “19 Tigers fans got infected with COVID-19 in NY.”
Explanation: Although it is true that members of the group “Libres y Lokos," a bar of a Monterrey soccer team, made a trip to New York to witness the game of Tigres versus New York City FC, it is false. As of 3/20/20, it has been confirmed that 19 people from the Blue-Blue Bar have contracted the new coronavirus as indicated by an audio circulating on WhatsApp.

What did you fact-check?: People with type O blood are more resistant to COVID-19.
Explanation: "It circulates on social networks and in various media portals, a note that ensures that a study establishes that certain blood groups are more resistant (or even immune) to the COVID-19 virus. This information is deceptive. This clinical trial is a preliminary study published on the medRxiv portal, a free online archive and distribution server for complete (unpublished) manuscripts from the medical, clinical and health-related sciences."

What did you fact-check?: Russia unleashed more than 500 lions on its streets to ensure that people are staying indoors during this pandemic outbreak.
Explanation: Russian President Vladimir Putin has not released lions in order to keep people inside during the COVID-19 pandemic.

What did you fact-check?: A purported warning from Australian hospitals has been shared thousands of times in multiple posts on Facebook that using petrol pumps can enable the spread of the novel coronavirus.
Explanation: The claim is false. Australia’s Department of Health said it did not issue the purported advisory; scientists say the virus is unlikely to survive on petrol pumps outside as sunlight and lack of moisture generally kill it; motorists are advised to regularly wash their hands to avoid infection.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus can live only up to 12 hours on any surface.
Explanation: According to a scientific study, coronavirus was stable on some surfaces (like plastic and stainless steel) for up to 72 hours (3 days). Also, the WHO website states the virus "may persist on surfaces for a few hours or up to several days."

What did you fact-check?: Video of Canadian PM Justin Trudeau’s wife who is suffering from COVID-19.
Explanation: Woman in the video is not the wife of Justin Trudeau but a COVID-19 patient from London.

What did you fact-check?: Autohemotherapy cures COVID-19.
Explanation: Auto-hemotherapy is not among the prevention or treatment measures for the new coronavirus recommended by national and international health authorities. Documents from medical entities and Anvisa (Brazilian National Health Surveillance Agency) published before the COVID-19 pandemic already warned of the risks of the practice, which has no scientific backing and may create health risks.

What did you fact-check?: The Brazilian government initiated the registration process for the coronavirus financial aid by WhatsApp.
Explanation: The message has been accompanied by links that can be used to steal personal data and redirect users to suspicious websites. The false information was denied by the Brazilian government and Ministries of Citizenship and Economy.

What did you fact-check?: Putin declares
Explanation: Exaggerated sanctions imposed on anyone who refuses to comply with the quarantine in Russia.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus is nothing but Sarin Gas.
Explanation: The claim that the outbreak is nothing but a cover for Sarin Gas leaks from an American lab in Afghanistan is false, according to the WHO.

What did you fact-check?: U.S. Army sells food just like the Egyptian Army.
Explanation: The photo, which shows the U.S. Army distributing free food in New York, is misleading.

What did you fact-check?: Pollution rate decreased in the aftermath of the coronavirus outbreak.
Explanation: Misbar found the claim is misleading; the pollution rate did decrease in some cities.

What did you fact-check?: Janta curfew or nationwide for 14 hours will break the chain of coronavirus spread and see a reduction of 40% of cases.
Explanation: There is no scientific proof to the claim.

Countries: North Macedonia, Croatia, Bosnia and Herzegovina
What did you fact-check?: A drug called Favipiravir is a cure for coronavirus, and people are advised not to go inside their homes wearing shoes because they can bring the infection home.
Explanation: Favipiravir may help treat those who have mild symptoms of COVID-19 but not those who are more severely ill. The director of the Spanish Center for Emergency Coordination Fernando Simon said on 3/16/20 that there was no need to leave shoes outside of the home. The same opinion is held by the head of the Italian Institute of Health, Silvio Brusaferro, and Fabrizio Preljasko, a virologist at the University of Milan.

What did you fact-check?: A chart comparing those infected and killed by the coronavirus in Argentina and Spain.
Explanation: The data on the chart is incorrect and it is not advised to compare and make projections with information from different countries experiencing the pandemic in different stages.

What did you fact-check?: Lukewarm water with lemon or water with lemon and bicarbonate are preventive measures for COVID-19.
Explanation: There is no scientific evidence that hot water or vitamin C prevents COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: Croatia to be put in “total quarantine” due to secret deal between authorities and the Red Cross.
Explanation: " The Red Cross doesn't have anything to do with implementing quarantine rules, nor did they attend a secret meeting with the Croatian government."

What did you fact-check?: Biden campaign claims a top CDC official was “silenced.”
Explanation: Messonnier’s remarks on 2/25/20 may have caught the attention of Wall Street and caused angst in the White House. But we cannot find evidence of her being immediately silenced, as Klain claims in the video.

What did you fact-check?: Denmark passed from 200 new cases of COVID-19 in one day to only 26 cases.
Explanation: These numbers are not in line with the national authorities. It was never reported there were 200 or 26 news cases in one day in Denmark. As of 3/19/20, there were 75 new cases in the country.

What did you fact-check?: Korean drama predicted the occurrence of COVID-19 in 2018.
Explanation: " The Korean series didn't talk about COVID-19 but used SARS as a reference in creating a highly lethal coronavirus with very different death rates, symptoms and incubation period."

What did you fact-check?: There are more than 6 000 coronavirus infections in Ukraine. The government hides the real numbers.
Explanation: The real numbers in any country are unknown. The aim of such claims is to spread panic.

What did you fact-check?: Pets can transmit the new coronavirus.
Explanation: There is no proof that pets can transmit the new coronavirus, although droplets with the virus can stay on pets and then infect humans.

What did you fact-check?: The quarantine in Italy showed more clean waters in Venice with fish and a dolphin.
Explanation: The claim is false. The image of a dolphin was taken in another Italian city, Cagliari, in the Sardinia island, and not in Venice. It was not due to the quarantine.

What did you fact-check?: Muammar Gaddafi predicted the current coronavirus pandemic, and warned it would be created by the same people who would then sell  the “antidotes.”
Explanation: In a speech to the UN General Assembly in 2009, the late Libyan leader did speculate about the creation of viruses and expressed his concern about the sale of vaccines. But he did not say the quote attributed to him, and he did not "predict" coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: A post shared thousands of times on Facebook lists companies whose chief executive officers have allegedly stepped down during the novel coronavirus crisis.
Explanation: Some of the 19 CEOs remain in their positions, while the announcements that others were leaving came before the virus emerged in late 2019.

What did you fact-check?: A video from a British broadcaster shows Italian coronavirus victims got taken down.
Explanation: The report is still available on Sky News and was not removed.

What did you fact-check?: Italy’s president was caught on camera crying over and regretting country’s coronavirus response.
Explanation: " The man in the video is not Italy's president. It was an older video of Brazil's president at a Thanksgiving service."

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus life span in a single place is 8 hours, and the Janata Curfew in India is for 14 hours. Thanks to 12 hours of Janata Curfew, the virus will be killed.
Explanation: Social distancing is important, but the viral post claiming a 14-hour break will kill COVID-19 Is misleading.

What did you fact-check?: This is a self-check test for coronavirus.
Explanation: Holding your breath for 10 seconds isn\'t a coronavirus "self-check test." Keeping your throat moist and drinking water every 15 minutes cannot kill coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Egypt discovered a treatment for COVID-19.
Explanation: Egypt MOH refuted the claim to Fatabyyano and later on its official Facebook page.

What did you fact-check?: Kazakhstanis could have had the coronavirus in the fall or winter 2019, but due to the lack of test systems at that time, the disease remained undetected.
Explanation: There is no convincing data to support this hypothesis. Neither the statistics of pneumonia incidence, nor the statements of authorized persons give grounds to believe that Kazakhstani people had the coronavirus long before the first cases were registered. Antibody tests have shown that the claim is unfounded.

What did you fact-check?: Media outlets duped the public saying coronavirus killed the same man twice.
Explanation: The man was both a police officer and professor, and two different stories used each title in the headline. However he did die of coronavirus complications.

What did you fact-check?: A photo that has gone viral in social media shows a military convoy transporting people who died from the COVID-19 pandemic in Italy.
Explanation: The photo in question is depicting a neighborhood in Paris and has no relation with the COVID-19 pandemic.

What did you fact-check?: An African plant called “vernonia” “kongolo bololo” or “ndolè” is useful against COVID-19.
Explanation: Nothing proves that this plant, that can be found in Central Africa, is a solution to cure or prevent COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: Claim that the outbreak of COVID-19 is not real.
Explanation: WHO, CDC, ECDC, Ministry of Health as well as multiple other agencies claim the outbreak is real.

What did you fact-check?: Claim that the outbreak of the virus was caused by 5G.
Explanation: No proof to link 5G network with the outbreak of the virus.

What did you fact-check?: Elderly people who are caught wandering outside in Brazil will have their pensions canceled by the government.
Explanation: INSS (government body responsible for paying the pensions to retirees) says no such measure has been considered.

What did you fact-check?: Photos show Maju Coutinho (a well known Brazilian journalist) walking around in Leblon beach with her boyfriend, even though she is urging people to stay inside during the pandemic.
Explanation: Pictures are from 2019.

What did you fact-check?: Burglars are disguised as health agents to invade and rob apartment buildings in Belo Horizonte and Goiânia.
Explanation: Police forces from Goiás and Minas Gerais deny these claims.

What did you fact-check?: Atacadão, a supermarket chain in Brazil, is distributing goods for free. You might get them if you leave a comment on the post.
Explanation: This is a scam used for acquiring Facebook logins and passwords.

What did you fact-check?: “The chloroquine stock in Paris hospitals was robbed”.
Who said/posted it?: Dr Perronne speech have been used by a well-known far-right Twitter account
Explanation: The chloroquine stocks had lowered drastically, but there have been no robbery.

What did you fact-check?: This graph compares coronavirus deaths with other diseases.
Explanation: Specialists emphasize that the comparison is misleading because it is a new virus that is still spreading and has not reached its "maximum circulation" like the other diseases mentioned.

What did you fact-check?: Romania is introducing a new law that will penalize breaking the quarantine with 15 years of imprisonment.
Explanation: 15 years of imprisonment is the maximum length of punishment for those who knowingly spread the contagious disease and their action results in death of others. Breaking the quarantine will be punishable up to 3 years of imprisonment or fine.

What did you fact-check?: COVID-19 was created in a lab to be used as a biological weapon.
Who said/posted it?: ZeroHegde, Urn Review, HispanTV, RT, Whatsapp users
Explanation: Nature Medicine magazine published on 3/17/20 that scientists have found COVID-19 is very different from other coronaviruses. There is no evidence of it being manipulated or created in a lab but it is a product of "natural selection." Sources are all-Moscow related and alt-right, with conspiracy theories and antisemitism approaches

What did you fact-check?: India will go under lockdown from 4/15/20 to 6/15/20.
Explanation: The Government Of India says this audio is fake and has no authenticity.

What did you fact-check?: Viral post claims that a COVID-19 infected patient was found in Hsipaw township hospital in Myanmar.
Explanation: Both ministry of health and sports and Hsipaw township medical superintendent have stated the patient had not contracted the COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: “Gale of the wind” and “Neem Tree” leaves are good medicine to protect from the coronavirus.
Who said/posted it?: Crime news Srilanka and number of Tamil FB Users
Explanation: As stated by WHO still there is no official remedy or cure for COVID-19, while some of the traditional methods have symptomatic improvements.

What did you fact-check?: Pope Francis ran away at a public meeting due to coronavirus fear.
Explanation: This video dates back to 2019 and is not related to COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: After COVID-19 outbreak in europe Muslims and non-Muslims have come out in the streets shouting praises for Allah and reading Kalma.
Explanation: Fact Crescendo found the viral video to be unrelated. The video dates back before the outbreak of COVID-19 in Europe. This is a demonstration march by the citizens in Hamburg, Germany in solidarity with Uyghur Muslims.

What did you fact-check?: Saddam Hussein predicted the coronavirus outbreak 40 years ago.
Explanation: " The video is edited and was shot before the Iraq war. In the video Saddam Hussein can be seen discussing prospects of war with his military advisors and son Qusay. There's no mention of coronavirus in the actual video."

What did you fact-check?: Eight COVID-19 patients in Ghana have recovered.
Explanation: The Ghana Health Service has rejected reports that 8 coronavirus patients in Ghana have recovered.

What did you fact-check?: Persons with blood type A are more prone to coronavirus.
Explanation: There is no scientific evidence to show that people with blood type A are more likely to get ‘COVID-19’.

What did you fact-check?: People with type A blood are more prone to get the new coronavirus.
Explanation: The study is preliminary and there is no scientific evidence that supports the relation between type blood and Covid-19.

What did you fact-check?: There’s definitive proof that chloroquine, hydroxychloroquine, are effective against COVID-19.
Explanation: " Studies have shown some early promise, but it's not entirely solid to say the treatments work against coronavirus."

What did you fact-check?: Fox News won Pulitzer for coronavirus coverage.
Explanation: Claim made on website that is clearly labeled as satire.

What did you fact-check?: WhatsApp chain sent by a doctor at Vall d’Hebron Hospital (Barcelona) about coronavirus
Explanation: " That doctor didn't write the chain, which makes some inaccurate claims."

What did you fact-check?: Video recorded by a Muslim resident in Spain who accumulates supplies for coronavirus
Explanation: The product brands shown in the video are Dutch.

What did you fact-check?: El País publishes that Renfe is proposing an ERTE for its employees due to the coronavirus.
Explanation: El Pais has not published this article and Renfe denies an ERTE is being considered.

What did you fact-check?: These remarks were made by Spanish Health official Fernando Simón “9 days ago”
Explanation: These remarks were made on January 31, not 9 days ago.

What did you fact-check?: MIlitary planes are going to fumigate the region of Comunidad Valenciana to disinfect it from coronavirus
Explanation: Ministry of Defense said there is not going to be such action.

What did you fact-check?: Speech from Spanish King Felipe VI about coronavirus was plagiarized from the book “Palmeras en la Nieve” or “Las Palmeras.”
Explanation: It is not the king\'s speech about coronavirus, but a speech from years ago about Catalonia. This speech was later included in the book "Las Palmeras." There is no plagiarism.

What did you fact-check?: A WhatsApp forward claims Prime Minister Narendra Modi called for a 14-hour long “Janta Curfew” on 3/22/20 from 7 a.m. to 9 p.m. because the lifespan of the coronavirus in one place is only 12 hours and if we all follow the Janta Curfew religiously, then the chain will be broken
Explanation: There is no clear information on the lifespan of the novel coronavirus. However, various studies have suggested a similar lifespan as that of other coronaviruses. PM Modi’s motive behind calling for a "Janta Curfew" was to curb the spread of novel coronavirus and the government has not claimed the Janta Curfew is called to kill the virus. The claim is misleading.

What did you fact-check?: Andhra Pradesh Chief Minister YS Jagan Reddy has claimed that Paracetamol is the only medication for coronavirus.
Explanation: It is evident from our findings and Dr. Pandey’s testimony that Paracetamol can help with coronavirus symptoms but cannot entirely cure it. We also found there are many medications that can help with coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: The United States of America threatened Iraq with coronavirus in 1990.
Explanation: According to the AP Archive description, Saddam Hussein said, “If God wills it and we have to run after the enemy, then we will do it.” Also, in AP’s description, we found that Saddam Hussein did not use the word "coronavirus" in the original video.

What did you fact-check?: Education Ministry will approve the exams of every student in Spain.
Explanation: The Ministry of Education debunks this claim.

What did you fact-check?: Vladimir Putin accused the “rest of the leaders” of having a plan to “reduce the world population.”
Explanation: The subtitles are manipulated.

What did you fact-check?: People are committing suicide due to the quarantine in Spain.
Explanation: National Police of Valencia confirms that the images shared are from last year.

What did you fact-check?: The new coronavirus created by China in a laboratory to “kill 1% of its population”.
Explanation: There is no evidence that coronavirus was created to kill 1% of Chinese population.

What did you fact-check?: Don’t take NSAIDs. This medicine worsens the symptom.
Explanation: The French health minister has made a similar statement while the health authorities of EU, UK and Taiwan said there is no enough evidence to support that claim.

What did you fact-check?: If you see a person wearing a white wristband, leave him alone. He is under quarantine.
Explanation: Electronic wristband are implemented in Hong Kong, not Taiwan. The picture is miscaptioned.

What did you fact-check?: The symptoms of the first nine days when one contracts COVID-19.
Explanation: " COVID-19 patients don't have the exact same symptoms. The most common symptoms are fever, tiredness and dry cough. Some patients may have aches and pains, nasal congestion, runny nose, sore throat or diarrhea."

What did you fact-check?: Many foreigners wiped their saliva onto the handle of Taipei’s metro to spread COVID-19.
Explanation: The videos were filmed in Hong Kong and Brussels, not in Taiwan.

What did you fact-check?: The spokesman for Chinese Foreign Ministry Zhao Lijian
Explanation: " China's Foreign Ministry spokesman Zhao Lijian tweeted and commanded."

What did you fact-check?: University of Vienna declares Ibuprofen makes the COVID-19 disease worse.
Explanation: University of Vienna denied the research. The relation between Ibuprofen intake and COVID-19 is still under investigation.

What did you fact-check?: Dr. Yavuz Dizdar’s multiple allegations around the COVID-19.
Explanation: Dr. Dizdar is an oncologist, not an expert in the field. The allegations are based on the interpretation, not scientific evidence.

What did you fact-check?: An audio clip suggests that the WHO has advised a lockdown.
Explanation: A source from the WHO confirmed that the organization has not put out any such information as heard on the viral audio clip.

What did you fact-check?: In an Ethiopian Airlines flight from Italy to Addis Ababa airport this evening, most of the passengers are infected with the virus, and there is no strength except in God.
Explanation: The visuals actually pertain to a mock rescue drill that took place at Blaise Diagne Airport near the town of Diass, Senegal. The incident dates back to 28 November 2019 and was a simple simulation aimed at evaluating the capacity to respond to various crises that may arise during airport operations.

What did you fact-check?: Saddam Hussein talked about coronavirus to his cabinet and army in the nineties. He said that America has threatened him to spread this virus if he doesn’t follow their command.
Explanation: The viral video is a doctored version of the original video shared by Associated Press in 2015. The audios of both the videos are different not only in terms of their content but voice as well. In the original AP video, Saddam Hussein does not mention the word ‘virus’ or ‘coronavirus.’

What did you fact-check?: Janta curfew in India will help break the chain of transmission.
Explanation: The WHO has maintained that it is not certain how long the virus that causes COVID-19 survives on surfaces, but it seems to behave like other coronaviruses.

What did you fact-check?: Hospitals are advising people to wear gloves at petrol pumps.
Explanation: The hospital named in the message confirmed that it did not issue this advice, and health authorities, including the Chief Medical Officer, said the public is not being advised to do this.

What did you fact-check?: Gargling with warm salt water can cure from the coronavirus.
Explanation: Post claiming gargling with warm salt water can save from coronavirus is fake as per health organizations and experts.

What did you fact-check?: The original form of the Corona COVID-19 virus after being enlarged 2,600 times
Explanation: Both ministry of health and sports and Sipaw township medical superintendent have issued patient had not contracted the COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: Video of the American Army distributing the coronavirus in China.
Explanation: The man in the first video is a train passenger in Belgium who is drunk. The man in the second video is a company manager in Hong Kong who intentionally made a parody video. The narrative that contains the conspiracy theory "the American army is the spreader of the Corona COVID-19 virus to China" comes from one Chinese official who has not been able to prove it.

What did you fact-check?: Gargling with warm water and salt or vinegar can kill coronavirus.
Explanation: An image shared on WhatsApp claims that gargling with warm water and salt or vinegar can kill COVID-19. There is no evidence that asserts the claims. The WHO says there is no medicine or household remedy to treat coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: President Donald Trump tried to buy a vaccine developed in Germany.
Explanation: In an audio, a woman said that Trump tried to buy a vaccine that was developed in Germany. However, the German CureVac Laboratory denied the allegations on 3/16/20.

What did you fact-check?: A WhatsApp message resembling an Nigerian CDC circular says Nigeria has not placed a travel ban or provided quarantine measures for travellers from countries with coronavirus cases.
Explanation: When the message was received, Nigeria was yet to establish travel restrictions; it has since imposed them on 13 high-risk countries. Contrary to the claim, have always been quarantine measures for migrants into the country.

What did you fact-check?: University of Vienna declares Ibuprofen makes the COVID-19 disease worse.
Explanation: University of Vienna denied the research. The relation between ibuprofen intake and COVID-19 is still under investigaion.

What did you fact-check?: Spain is the European country where the coronavirus is more lethal.
Explanation: Spain is not the European country where the coronavirus is most lethal; it is Italy.

What did you fact-check?: Spaniards need to carry a work certificate or purchase receipts to justify to the Security Forces why they have taken to the streets under the state of alarm.
Explanation: It is not mandatory, but it helps to facilitate police controls.

What did you fact-check?: Chloroquine cures COVID-19.
Explanation: Studies on chloroquine are ongoing and are not conclusive.

What did you fact-check?: A post has been shared tens of thousands of times on Facebook and Twitter which claims that a factory in the Australian city of Melbourne has been hoarding essential supplies including baby formula, toilet paper and hand sanitiser for export to China during the novel coronavirus pandemic.
Explanation: The claim is false; police said the accusation was "false". The company cited in the misleading posts also refuted the claim.

What did you fact-check?: Chloroquine was forbidden by a French government decree in January.
Who said/posted it?: Online article with a screenshot of a legal decree
Explanation: The legal decree did not forbid chloroquine, but sets up a new requirement for a prescription. This change followed a recommendation of the National Agence of Medicine (ANSM), made on 12/13/19, before the outbreak of coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: A post giving a nurse’s advice not to be infected by coronavirus. The nurse is called Claire Magne and works at hospitals in Toulouse, or in Marseille, depending on publications.
Explanation: Quoted hospitals in the publications both denied to AFP having a Claire Magne working for them.

What did you fact-check?: An audio circulating on WhatsApp says the way to end the COVID-19 pandemic is by “creating herd immunity groups.” Supposedly, it is a group of people who, thanks to their “positive thoughts and diet,,” manage to “alkalize their body” and prevent the virus from spreading.
Explanation: Immunity is not achieved through food or the mind.

What did you fact-check?: Deputy of the Movement to Socialism (MAS) in Bolivia, Juana Quispe Ari
Explanation: Medical information about the disease explains why this is not true.

What did you fact-check?: Bolivian Government Minister, Arturo Murillo, said that COVID-19 “is a type of cold”.
Who said/posted it?: Arturo Murillo, Government Minister of Bolivia
Explanation: The Bolivian former minister of Health, Guillermo Cuentas Yañez replies

What did you fact-check?: The Whatsapp audio that states absolute quarantine in Bolivia is from Andrés Rojas, the CEO of Bolivia TV.
Explanation: Bolivia Verifica contacted the deputy of Movement of Socialism (MAS), Franklin Flores, who denied that the audio is from Bolivia. He also explained that when it (The state of Bolivia) comes to emergency, no law projects are carried out.

What did you fact-check?: Ugandan landlords have been asked by the government to stop collecting rent as citizens stay home to fight COVID-19.
Explanation: A letter allegedly from State House Uganda directing landlords in the country to stop collecting rent as Ugandans stay home to fight COVID-19 is not authentic.

What did you fact-check?: An article claims that a Kenyan died from COVID-19 on 3/20/20.
Explanation: The article is false.

What did you fact-check?: An image of coffins showing the victims of COVID-19 in Italy.
Explanation: A Facebook post with an image claiming to show the victims of COVID-19 in Italy uses a photo of the coffins of African immigrants who drowned off the coast near Lampedusa in 2013.

What did you fact-check?: Persons with blood type A are more prone to coronavirus.
Explanation: There is no scientific evidence to show that people with blood type A are more likely to get ‘Covid-19’.

What did you fact-check?: An image of coffins in Italy.
Explanation: The image was taken in 2013.

What did you fact-check?: President Rodrigo Duterte said COVID-19, the disease caused by the novel coronavirus, is only transmitted through contact with other people.
Explanation: The novel coronavirus is known to spread mainly from person to person, but it can also spread through infected surfaces or objects.

What did you fact-check?: U.S. President Donald Trump said in a White House briefing on 3/20/20 that chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine, which are often used to treat malaria, have been approved by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) for treatment of COVID-19.
Explanation: Chloroquine or hydroxychloroquine is FDA-approved for treating malaria, lupus and rheumatoid arthritis, but not COVID-19. There is no official cure for the disease as of 3/25/20.

What did you fact-check?: Says truck drivers are being turned away from fast-food restaurants during the COVID-19 pandemic.
Explanation: " Truck drivers are having issues getting meals at some fast-food chains with shuttered dining rooms. Their rigs can't fit in drive-thru lanes and they aren't allowed to walk up and order at the window."

What did you fact-check?: This picture show dozens of coffins in Italy because of the coronavirus.
Explanation: This pictures has been taken in 2013, it has no links with the current pandemia.

What did you fact-check?: It is forbidden to be more than one in a car in France during the lockdown.
Explanation: You have to follow some rules, but it is not always forbidden.

What did you fact-check?: 1720, 1919, 2020… Every hundred years, a pandemia “cleans” the Earth.
Explanation: Multiples pandemia occurred outside of this timeframe.

What did you fact-check?: The French Education Minister has postponed the summer holidays because of the coronavirus outbreak.
Explanation: The minister said the measure is not being considered at the moment.

What did you fact-check?: “Wisconsin is the only state where all Republicans voted against protecting its citizens.”
Explanation: Wisconsin is indeed the only one of the 50 states where all Republicans voted no. But it’s a bit of an exaggeration to describe that vote as “against protecting its citizens.”

What did you fact-check?: “Fish tank additive may treat coronavirus.”
Explanation: Fish-tank cleaners containing chloroquine cannot be substituted for prescription drugs used to treat malaria. The FDA says you should not take chloroquine unless it has been prescribed by a doctor and obtained from a legitimate source.

What did you fact-check?: Romania is introducing new law that will penalize breaking the quarantine with 15 years of imprisonment.
Explanation: 15 years of imprisonment is maximum length of punishment for those who knowingly spread the contagious disease and their action resulted in death of others. Breaking the quarantine will be punishable up to 3 years of imprisonment or fine.

What did you fact-check?: Italian doctor saying no one has died from coronavirus.
Explanation: " The source is from late February when the coronavirus outbreak in Italy wasn't that significant. At the moment, this doctor has changed his position on coronavirus and casualties."

What did you fact-check?: Audio message warns of the arrival of COVID-19 at Suba hospital in Columbia.
Explanation: Health entities in the capital confirmed that this is misinformation. So far, there are no cases of coronavirus in the Suba hospital.

What did you fact-check?: Audio clip of a conversation claiming that Government of India will announce shutdown of the country in the coming days from 4/15/20 to 6/15/20 in the wake of the coronavirus outbreak
Explanation: PIB found the audio clip of the phone conversation discussing a "complete lockdown" of the country to be fake. WHO India has also confirmed the audio is fake.

What did you fact-check?: People shouting “Allahu Akbar” in Europe after the coronavirus outbreak.
Explanation: The video is not related to the COVID-19 outbreak in Europe. It was found on the internet since 1/13/20, and the first COVID-19 case in Europe was reported on 1/24/20. The video was taken in Germany, where the first COVID-19 case was reported on 1/28/20.

What did you fact-check?: Government of India has announced a “National Lockdown” in the country from 3/20/20.
Explanation: The Government of India has not announced a "National Lockdown" in the country from 3/20/20. PM Modi, in his recent address to the nation about the coronavirus outbreak, asked people to practice social distancing and to stay home as much as possible for the coming few weeks to combat COVID-19. The Press Information Bureau (PIB) said the message is fake.

What did you fact-check?: Indian PM Modi is providing free masks to people under Swachh Bharat Mission to protect them from the coronavirus outbreak.
Explanation: The website in the post is dubious and there is no government scheme of PM Modi under which free masks are being provided to people. The Press Information Bureau (PIB) said there is no central government scheme that provides free masks to people to protect them from the coronavirus outbreak.

What did you fact-check?: Recently, Petrol companies reduced Rs. 6.40 on petrol and on Diesel Rs. 6.80.
Explanation: The petrol and diesel price have not reduced by Rs.6

What did you fact-check?: Saudi English-language magazine Sayidaty addresses novel coronavirus since 2013
Explanation: The magazine addressed the Middle East respiratory coronavirus back then, which means the claim is misleading.

What did you fact-check?: Brazilian President declares “Gaza is the only coronavirus free city”.
Explanation: Misbar investigated the claim and found that the Arabic translation accompanying the video is fake.

What did you fact-check?: Italian prime minister Conte
Explanation: Misbar investigated the claim and found that it is fake; no such statement had been released from the PM on any official record.

What did you fact-check?: Video shows a woman falling down in Jeddah.
Explanation: Misbar investigated the video and found that the woman is mentally unstable, which caused her to fall, according to Saudi authorities.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus fears in Germany result in large crowds outside the supermarket.
Explanation: The viral video is 9 years old and has nothing to do with COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: Donald Trump said, “People are dying who have never died before”
Explanation: The quote has been on the internet for over a decade attributing it to different people at different times.

What did you fact-check?: Not a single Muslim died of coronavirus in China.
Explanation: There is no such claim made by China so far that not a single Muslim has died of coronavirus. China has not released a list of people who have died from coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: You shouldn’t open your windows.
Explanation: A study published in the New England Journal of Medicine warned that the novel coronavirus remains viable for up to three hours in the air, four hours on copper coins, a whole day on cardboard surfaces and as long as two or three days on plastic surfaces or stainless steel faucets. This scientific data went viral on social media as an oversimplified, false message

What did you fact-check?: The Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act gives members of Congress a pay increase.
Explanation: No version of the coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act grants pay raises for members of Congress.

What did you fact-check?: Because of the COVID-19 epidemic, an ice rink is turned to a morgue in Mulhouse (France).
Explanation: The rumor that spread on social networks was denied by the city, the president of the hockey team and by a witness with photos. Also, an ice rink would not be an efficient morgue.

What did you fact-check?: Five helicopters are spraying disinfectants over German cities.
Explanation: There are no helicopters spraying disinfectants over Germany and there are no plans to do so.

What did you fact-check?: Favipiravir is a miracle cure for COVID-19.
Explanation: " Favipiravir is among the drugs being tested to treat COVID-19 but there's no proof it can cure the disease."

What did you fact-check?: Arbidol is a miracle cure for COVID-19.
Explanation: " Arbidol is among the drugs being tested to treat COVID-19 but there's no proof it can cure the disease."

What did you fact-check?: A post claims that there are no cases of the new coronavirus in Russia.
Explanation: In the day that the post was published there were already 147 people infected with COVID-19, according to the national authorities.

What did you fact-check?: Using hot air from a hair dryer on sinuses can prevent and treat COVID-19
Explanation: No evidence supports this theory. Directing hot air to sinuses will make them dry which cause tiny tears that may increase the risk of COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: A runny nose is not a COVID-19 symptom.
Explanation: A fever and dry cough are the most common symptoms of COVID-19. Runny nose also one. In Thailand, 25% of patients had a runny nose.

What did you fact-check?: A video has been viewed thousands of times on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram and YouTube in March 2020 alongside a claim that it shows police in Spain detaining people during a lockdown due to the coronavirus pandemic.
Explanation: The claim is false. The video has circulated in reports about an anti-government protest in Azerbaijan in October 2019.

What did you fact-check?: Romania has changed the law so that those who break the quarantine will face 15 years in prison.
Explanation: 15 years is maximum potential punishment (from 7 up to 15 years of imprisonment) but not for those who break the quarantine; it is for those infected who willingly spread contagious disease resulting in the death of other people.

What did you fact-check?: Recording of a conversation where one claims to be a friend of the WHO India Director’s brother, Saurabh, who gave him information that India will go into a complete lockdown mode from 4/15/20April to 6/15/20.
Explanation: WHO’s official in SEARO confirmed the viral audio on social media is "fake."

What did you fact-check?: Bitter gourd juice can cure coronavirus in just two hours.
Explanation: PIB India clarified that this viral message is fake. According to the WHO, there is no cure for coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Ibuprofen is not good as a possible COVID-19 treatment.
Explanation: The University of Vienna denied the research. The relation between Ibuprofen and COVID-19 is not clear yet.

What did you fact-check?: A photo of coffins of dead people as a result of the new coronavirus.
Explanation: The images were taken in October 2013.

What did you fact-check?: People with type A blood are more prone to get the new coronavirus.
Explanation: The study is preliminary and there is no scientific evidence that supports the relation between blood type and COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: Persons with type A blood are more prone to the coronavirus.
Explanation: There is no scientific evidence to show that people with type A blood are more likely to get COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus is spreading rapidly on gas pumps.
Explanation: Experts confirm it can spread on gas pumps but not more than on any other location.

What did you fact-check?: Retirement cut for elderly people who take to the streets during quarantine.
Explanation: Message circulating on WhatsApp simulates a Social Security statement and cites a provisional measure, which is unrelated to the COVID-19 pandemic.

What did you fact-check?: Ambev company will distribute hand sanitizer to the population.
Explanation: The company will distribute alcoholic gel to health establishments, not to the entire population.

What did you fact-check?: Using sauna or aiming a hairdryer at one’s nose will kill the coronavirus.
Explanation: " Expert in infectious diseases said it won't make any impact against coronavirus, and the heat could be damaging if excessive."

What did you fact-check?: Belgium’s health minister banned sex inside or with 3 or more people.
Explanation: This is a satirical article.

What did you fact-check?: Bill Gates has access to your DNA and ownership in WHO.
Explanation: Gates is not behind testing because each country does that themselves.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus is an illusion and the cause of COVID-19 is the 5G signal.
Explanation: " The virus was found in the secretions of patients all over the world which is detected by PCR. COVID-19 is present in countries that didn't support 5G until now."

What did you fact-check?: If everybody was vegan, we wouldn’t see a coronavirus epidemic. Infograph in English.
Explanation: " It's impossible to prevent coronavirus on a planet co-inhabited by humans and animals."

What did you fact-check?: Cattle vaccine proofs that coronavirus has existed for years and that there already is a vaccine. Photo showing the cattle vaccine produced by the American medical company ScourGuard 4KC.
Explanation: "The coronavirus is not new at all, and cattle have been vaccinated against the virus for years," reads a statement that is widely shared on social media. But there are two different branches of the same virus, which is why vaccination for cattle does not work against COVID-19 disease, which is currently ravaging the world.

What did you fact-check?: The PCR tests have a false result in 30 to 50 percent of cases, they are not reliable.
Explanation: There is no proof for this claim, experts say the test is reliable.

What did you fact-check?: Muslim Doctor died while treating people infected with coronavirus in Delhi
Explanation: The viral post is fake. The muslim doctor, as shown in the viral post, did not die while treating people infected with coronavirus in Delhi.

What did you fact-check?: A sanitary Glade product says it is effective against the coronavirus.
Explanation: No studies have yet been done to demonstrate Glade effectiveness on COVID-19

What did you fact-check?: The Mexican government is going to spray the residents with toxic substances. They will also inject villagers with COVID-19. Consequently, some residents closed roads.
Explanation: The authorities have already denied these claims. This disinformation is a mixture of other false statements that have also already been denied.

What did you fact-check?: The new coronavirus was patented by the Pasteur Institute.
Explanation: Although the Pasteur Institute has a 2004 coronavirus patent, it is not related to COVID-19. In fact, the fact that virus patents are filed does not mean that they have been created.

What did you fact-check?: Giant hornets migrated to Europe due to the outbreak of coronavirus.
Explanation: The authors of the article stole older material on hornets and climate change and wrote headline about coronavirus

What did you fact-check?: Photo shows row of coffins in Italy. Claims that this is how Bergamo in Italy deals with the dead from the virus.
Explanation: The photo was taken in 2013, amidst the migration crisis.

What did you fact-check?: Video showing police beating people in China, linked with the outbreak.
Explanation: The video shows police beating people in Hong Kong. The video was shot on the last day of August 2019.

What did you fact-check?: COVID-19 existed before 2019.
Explanation: This is false because the coronaviruses affecting cattle or canines differ from the new virus strain affecting humans, for which no vaccine exists.

What did you fact-check?: Hot air from saunas, hair dryers will prevent or treat COVID-19.
Explanation: This is false because an expert said these methods would not be effective, while a cell biologist said there is no evidence the virus can be treated via heat.

What did you fact-check?: A purported advisory has been shared repeatedly in multiple Facebook, Twitter and WhatsApp posts that claims a disinfectant will be sprayed into the air overnight in India in an effort to kill the novel coronavirus, COVID-19. The posts urge residents to remain indoors during the spraying.
Explanation: The claim is false; Indian authorities said the advisory was "fake" and that no such measure had been announced.

What did you fact-check?: In France, Mulhouse’s ice rink has been converted into a morgue.
Explanation: Mulhouse city hall and a hockey club, which is used to practising on this rink, had denied the claim.

What did you fact-check?: People who replied to a French government text with texts saying they won’t respect confinement measures are now facing justice.
Explanation: The Nanterre Court denied having received any instruction to prosecute senders of these messages, and the messages present many inconsistencies.

What did you fact-check?: The RDC government canceled every future exams for pupils, because of coronavirus.
Explanation: The minister of Education, Willy Bakonga, denied this claim to AFP.

What did you fact-check?: Netflix is offering free access to anyone in Brazil during the coronavirus crisis.
Explanation: Netflix is not offering free services during the pandemic. The URL used is not a Netflix domain.

What did you fact-check?: Petrobras (Brazil’s largest oil company) is closing its refineries from March 24th onwards.
Explanation: The alleged press release did not come from Petrobras. Refineries are not going to be shut down for now.

What did you fact-check?: A man claims his dog was vaccinated for coronavirus, thus the SARS-Cov-2 is not really a new virus.
Explanation: Canine coronavirus (CCov) and the novel coronavirus are not the same virus.

What did you fact-check?: Uber will suspend operations for 10 days in Brazil due to the pandemic.
Explanation: The alleged announcement did not come from Uber, and the company will not stop working during the crisis.

What did you fact-check?: Popular Cardiologist Devi Shetty talking about symptoms of COVID-19.
Explanation: The person in question is a different doctor and not the famous cardiologist.

What did you fact-check?: India asked for restriction of movement.
Explanation: The notification is from Malaysia and not India.

What did you fact-check?: India spraying pesticides at night to prevent COVID-19.
Explanation: Officials stated that no pesticides were being sprayed.

What did you fact-check?: Image claims to show dozens of coffins of Italians who have died from COVID-19.
Explanation: The photo actually shows the caskets of African migrants who died in a 2013 shipwreck off the coast of Italy.

What did you fact-check?: In this video Putin said
Explanation: The captions were changed to make people believe that the Russian president said things he did not say at the time.\nThe video was recorded at an event commemorating World War II.

What did you fact-check?: Spaniards are violating quarantine rules.
Explanation: The video was recorded in October 2019 days before the exhumation of the remains of the dictator Francisco Franco.

What did you fact-check?: The recommendations against coronavirus in the viral WhatsApp audio were made by the owner of Swiss Medical (private health insurance company).
Explanation: A report by the Conicet Sensory Research Laboratory indicates that, although it is limited, there is evidence that the audio does not belong to the businessman.\nThe company denied that the audio was recorded by the president of the company.

What did you fact-check?: The WHO recommended that all countries go into quarantine to combat COVID-19.
Explanation: In networks and the media, it has been stated that the World Health Organization, WHO, "recommended that all countries declare themselves in quarantine to combat COVID-19". However, the WHO itself denied it.

What did you fact-check?: A video shows the Russian leader Vladimir Putin, giving a speech with captions that make him seem like he is rebuking world leaders.
Explanation: " A video shared on Facebook and Twitter in which Vladimir Putin, the President of Russia, is seen giving a speech in front of a crowd. The video comes with Spanish subtitles that make it appear that he is criticizing the leaders of other countries for their recent actions. Some social network users even shared the video as if this were Putin's response to how other countries are handling the crisis."

What did you fact-check?: The coronavirus was created in a biological laboratory in Wuhan.
Explanation: " There is no evidence that 'the coronavirus comes from a biological laboratory in Wuhan,' as claimed by Mexican youtuber Alexander Backman."

What did you fact-check?: Polish charity organisation WOSP has withdrawn its donation to coronavirus fight in Poland.
Explanation: " There was no decision of backing down whatsoever. WOSP couldn't possibly donate the money it collected during public gathering as there was clearly stated goal for that gathering that can't be changed afterwards. WOSP is involved in many activities supporting coronavirus fight."

What did you fact-check?: You no longer need to have contact with someone to get the coronavirus.
Explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

What did you fact-check?: You no longer need to have contact with someone to get the coronavirus.
Explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

What did you fact-check?: Donald Trump said about coronavirus, “People are dying who have never died before.”
Explanation: Ernest Hemingway said it.

What did you fact-check?: IDH Hospital, the main center in Sri Lanka for treating COVID-19 patients, is in shortage of number of essentials.
Explanation: We contacted both doctors and health officials and confirmed that there is no shortage of goods at the hospital as of yet and the messages were fabricated.

What did you fact-check?: Clean your throat with salt water or vinegar to cure coronavirus.
Explanation: Experts confirmed this is a false claim.

What did you fact-check?: Spanish minister of agriculture called out football players for earning too much and showing lack of solidarity.
Explanation: The minister never made the statement attributed to her.

What did you fact-check?: You should leave your shoes outside, as they carry the virus.
Explanation: Official sources say this is not true.

What did you fact-check?: These images show coffins of COVID-19 victims in Italy.
Explanation: Images in question were actually taken in 2013.

What did you fact-check?: Chinese claim that the virus was created in 2015 in US.
Explanation: There is no evidence that supports this claim.

What did you fact-check?: Ibuprofen aggravates patients with the new coronavirus.
Explanation: There is no scientific evidence that conclusively proves ibuprofen aggravates coronavirus patients.

What did you fact-check?: 5G technology caused the coronavirus.
Explanation: Historical events were conflated, and did not back up claims with real evidence.

What did you fact-check?: WHO director overstated COVID-19 fatality rate as higher than flu.
Explanation: CDC data and doctors said that coronavirus has a much higher mortality rate than flu.

What did you fact-check?: Walmart is closing hundreds of its stores.
Explanation: This story is several years old, and there has been no recent announcement.

What did you fact-check?: Cristiano Ronaldo bought private island to escape coronavirus.
Explanation: " Ronaldo's management company confirmed it was false."

What did you fact-check?: Trump said “people are dying who have never died before”.
Explanation: Searches in databases of the phrase never show up. Other fact checks confirm fabrication.

What did you fact-check?: Obama family flown to private island to escape coronavirus pandemic.
Explanation: Website has visible disclaimers saying it is purely satire.

What did you fact-check?: Link takes viewers to application for FEMA assistance in the US.
Explanation: Link just takes you to a meme picture.

What did you fact-check?: Cuba has a vaccine against the coronavirus called Interferón.
Explanation: The interferon is a drug used in certain countries to mitigate the spread of COVID-19, but it is not a vaccine.

What did you fact-check?: Cuba’s health ministry, Dr. Hala, has given the vaccine against the coronavirus to China.
Explanation: For the moment, there is no vaccine against COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: The parks of Adra, in Spain, are being fumigated with poison.
Explanation: Local and national police explain to Newtral.es that it is not true.

What did you fact-check?: Drinking water every 15 minutes helps to avoid the contagion of cononavirus.
Explanation: It is false that drinking water every 15 minutes helps to avoid COVID-19 by "cleaning" your throat.

What did you fact-check?: Katy Perry, Madonna and Black Sabbath shared videos of Italy’s flash mob with fake audio.
Explanation: All the videos have real images but fake audios. In the first case – Katy Perry – Italians are singing the song Roar instead of the national anthem (real video). In the second case – Madonna and Black Sabbath – Italians are singing I rise or War pigs instead of Macarena (real video).

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus stays in throat for four days before arriving lungs. Gargling with salt water or vinegar kills the coronavirus.
Explanation: There is no evidence that rinsing your mouth with salty water or vinegar can prevent COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: A magic remedy to prevent COVID-19
Explanation: There is no evidence that the recipe can prevent or cure COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: Remedy recipe
Explanation: There is no evidence that the recipe can prevent or cure COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: Video shows how American soldiers spread coronavirus during 7th CISM Military World Game in Wuhan.
Explanation: The video happened in Brussels on march. It has not happened in Wuhan or Taipei.

What did you fact-check?: Italians played the Chinese national anthem to thank China. People yelled “Grazie Cina”.
Explanation: It\'s a video of Italian expressing gratitude to medical staff. The soundtrack of "Grazie China" and the Chinese national anthem was edited into the original video

What did you fact-check?: A dog in Hong Kong died of COVID-19.
Explanation: " Vets shared the test results with Teyit. Dog's tests were negative for COVID-19."

What did you fact-check?: Video shows a balcony party in the Turkish capital Ankara due to quarantine.
Explanation: The video is originally from Spain and manipulated with a Turkish song on top of it.

What did you fact-check?: Korean series My Secret Terrius predicted the outbreak in advance.
Explanation: The series was about an international conspiracy, not an outbreak. The fictional virus was quite different from the current one.

What did you fact-check?: Sitting in the sunlight will help cure coronavirus.
Who said/posted it?: Minister of State, Health, Ashwini Choubey
Explanation: The answer to this statement, according to doctors, is more than just true or false. Professor Ramanan Laxminarayan, Director of Centre for Disease Dynamics, Economics and Policy (CDDEP) said that, “We do not know how heat will affect this coronavirus as of yet. Usually, respiratory pathogens disappear in the summer and in the heat, but we have seen many cases in tropical countries too.”

What did you fact-check?: China recognizes Palestinian doctor as discoverer of coronavirus vaccine
Explanation: Not a single report was discovered about the discovery of the Corona vaccine by Palestinian doctors. Even the doctor who claimed to be the inventor of the vaccine, Manar Saadi Al-Sheenawi, was not found in the Google search engine. In addition, until now, the WHO has not announced the discovery of any vaccine that can treat COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: Drinking water every 15 minutes helps to avoid the contagion of cononavirus.
Explanation: It is false that drinking water every 15 minutes helps to avoid Covid-19 by "cleaning" your throat.

What did you fact-check?: An audio message shared by Whatsapp users affirms that COVID-19 dies at 27° Celsius.
Explanation: It is still unknown whether weather and temperature will affect the spread of COVID-19. According to the United States Center for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), it is currently unknown whether the spread of COVID-19 is reduced in hot seasons.

What did you fact-check?: An audio broadcast on Whatsapp indicates that garlic helps to overcome diseases such as the coronavirus.
Explanation: According to the World Health Organization (WHO), garlic is a healthy food that may have some antimicrobial properties. However, no evidence has been obtained that eating it protects against COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: An audio message shared by Whatsapp users affirms that COVID-19 dies at 27° Celsius.
Explanation: It is still unknown whether weather and temperature will affect the spread of COVID-19. According to the United States Center for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), it is currently unknown whether the spread of COVID-19 is reduced in hot seasons.

What did you fact-check?: Beverages like ‘akpeteshie’, a local Ghanaian brewed spirit made from sugarcane or palm wine, can be used as a substitute for hand sanitizers.
Explanation: Herbal and local gin bitters often do not meet the required alcohol content for an effective hand rub. Thus, they may not be good substitutes for hand sanitizers against the COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: Allegations that garlic and a cold shower helps to avoid COVID-19.
Explanation: " Doctors say garlic, coal and cold shower don't prevent COVID-19."

What did you fact-check?: Martial law is imminent in United States.
Explanation: U.S. governments are not planning to implement martial law; National Guard is providing aid and support for communities.

What did you fact-check?: A video of US President Donald Trump and a top US pharmaceutical executive speaking at a press conference has been viewed thousands of times in multiple Facebook, Twitter and YouTube posts alongside a claim that it shows them announcing a vaccine for the novel coronavirus, COVID-19, was “ready” to be administered.
Explanation: The claim is false; neither Trump nor the pharmaceutical executive make any reference to a vaccine being "ready" for distribution; as of March 2020, the World Health Organization (WHO) states there is not yet a vaccine for COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: A screenshot of a purported internal email disclosing that a bank in the Pakistani city of Rawalpindi was closed after an employee tested positive for the novel coronavirus, COVID-19, has been shared on Facebook, Twitter and WhatsApp.
Explanation: The claim is false; the bank said in a statement that “no employee at any” branch had tested positive for COVID-19, and that all branches remained “open and fully operative.”

What did you fact-check?: Homemade recipes for alcohol gel.
Explanation: Making alcohol gel at home is not recommended by medical authorities; it can be ineffective and dangerous.

What did you fact-check?: Netflix is offering free access for those in quarantine.
Explanation: Netflix has not announced free access; message on WhatsApp is a phishing scam.

What did you fact-check?: Posts circulating on social media claim that Ugandan and Kenyan authorities have instructed landlords to stop collecting rent due to the novel coronavirus.
Explanation: The claim is false; the countries have issued public guidance amid the pandemic, but there has been no official communication on rent payments and government officials dismissed the reports.

What did you fact-check?: Crocodiles were spotted swimming in the canals of Venice without the bustle of tourists.
Explanation: The photo is a composite image making up of two photographs.

What did you fact-check?: The canals in Venice have become cleaner after the shutdown, attracting schools of fish and dolphins.
Explanation: The video was filmed in Cagliari, Italy, a harbor city 743 kilometers away from Venice.

What did you fact-check?: Four men were tested positive to COVID-19 in Cameroon and ran away from the hospital.
Explanation: " These four men published many videos on Facebook to debunk this claim. They also told AFP they lived in Italy. Cameroon's Health ministry also told AFP those four men don't belong to the group of people who are in quarantine in Cameroon."

What did you fact-check?: A private lab was denied authorization to perform COVID-19 test.
Explanation: The government only authorizes the National Lab to perform COVID-19 tests.

What did you fact-check?: Gargling salt water can protect against against COVID-19 by washing down the virus into the gut.
Explanation: Gargling salt water is not a recommended protective measure against COVID-19, and has been debunked by the World Health Organization.

What did you fact-check?: Tanzanian club spokesman Haji S. Manara was infected with COVID-19 during his tour of The Netherlands.
Explanation: " Tanzania's Simba Sports Club spokesman Haji S. Manara does not have COVID-19 as claimed, and he was tested after leaving Spain and when he entered the Netherlands."

What did you fact-check?: The World Health Organization is offering free internet for the public to access information about COVID-19.
Explanation: A link circulating on WhatsApp claiming that the World Health Organization is offering free internet to help people access information on COVID-19 is a hoax.

What did you fact-check?: Fake quote of Senator of the Philippines Francis “Kiko” Pangilinan saying he wants children to be exempted from the lockdown.
Explanation: Pangilinan did not say the quote attributed to him. News5 also said the graphic did not come from any of their official social media accounts.

What did you fact-check?: Agnès Buzyn, former french minister of Health, took chloroquine out of a list of drugs that could be sold over the counter when the coronavirus started to spread.
Explanation: The decision was taken before the COVID-19 crisis began.

What did you fact-check?: Claim that “there is no” COVID-19 virus.
Explanation: The coronavirus is real and infecting thousands of people around the world. As of March 19, COVID-19 had infected more than 191,000 people around the world and resulted in 7,807 deaths.

What did you fact-check?: The federal government is “preparing to mobilize the national guard,” “dispatch them across the US with military” and “announce a nationwide 1 week quarantine for all citizens.”
Explanation: There is no evidence that the federal government is set to announce a lockdown. White House officials have repeatedly said it’s not something they’re considering at this time.

What did you fact-check?: For coronavirus cases “in the U.S. 38% of those hospitalized are under 35.”
Explanation: The CDC reported that between mid-February and mid-March, 20% of the hospitalizations for coronavirus were for patients age 20-44 and 18% were age 45-54.

What did you fact-check?: “Huge! Results From Breaking Chloroquine Study Show 100% Cure Rate For Patients Infected With The coronavirus.”
Explanation: A French study of 20 COVID-19 patients indicates the drug might help treat the coronavirus. But it is no “100% cure.”

What did you fact-check?: According to Art. 116 of the Constitution, a “state of emergency” will be implemented in Mexico that will limit the free movement of people to combat the #COVID-19 epidemic.
Explanation: The mentioned article is in the Spanish Constitution, not in the Mexican. Article 116 of the Spanish Constitution speaks of the state of alarm. And to avoid leaving you in doubt, constitutional 116 (the one in Mexico) talks about the division of powers, not "states of emergency."

What did you fact-check?: Video broadcast on networks allegedly shows the ‘first killed by COVID-19 in Ibagué’, in Columbia.
Explanation: The images were taken out of context. It is actually the first coronavirus patient in this city to be discharged from the hospital.

What did you fact-check?: Video of passengers infected with coronavirus on an Ethiopian Airlines flight from Italy that reached Addis Ababa airport.
Explanation: The video is of an ‘Emergency Exercise’ at Blaise Diagne International Airport (Senegal) in November 2019. So, the video is of a drill that was conducted a month earlier before the first coronavirus case was detected in China.

What did you fact-check?: Press Release on movement restriction for COVID-19 outbreak by National Security Council, PMO (India).
Explanation: The press release in the post was issued by the Malaysian Government, not by the Indian Government.

What did you fact-check?: BBMP (Bruhat Bengaluru Mahanagara Palike) will be spraying medicine in the air after 10 PM tonight in order to kill COVID-19.
Explanation: The BBMP Commissioner and the Mayor have clarified that the message is just a rumor and the BBMP has no such plans to spray any medicine for COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: Scientists have found that drinking bitter gourd juice can cure coronavirus.
Explanation: " The World Health Organization (WHO) or the Ministry for Health & Family Welfare (India) hasn't announced that drinking bitter gourd juice will cure coronavirus. The Press Information Bureau (PIB) has clarified that the message is ‘fake’."

What did you fact-check?: This video shows goats affected by the coronavirus.
Explanation: The video is an old one. It was taken before the recent coronavirus outbreak. Also, the Minister for Animal Husbandry, Dairying and Fisheries has clarified that there is no evidence to show that eating mutton can transmit coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Gargling warm water with either salt or vinegar can eliminate coronavirus.
Explanation: The World Health Organisation (WHO) or Indian government has not mentioned anywhere that the gargling of warm water with salt or vinegar can eliminate coronavirus. Indian government’s Press Information Bureau (PIB) has also said that the message that was circulating on social media is fake.

What did you fact-check?: An audio clip claiming to be of renowned heart surgeon Dr Devi Shetty is going viral on Facebook, Twitter, and WhatsApp.
Explanation: The viral clip has been falsely attributed to Dr Devi Shetty.

What did you fact-check?: Indian government to spray medicine in the air overnight to kill coronavirus.
Explanation: There is no such government order for residents of Chandigarh, Bengaluru, or any other city that government would spread medicine in air to destroy coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Leader of North Korea Kim Jong-Un visits an infected woman without wearing a mask.
Explanation: The photo dates back to April 2018.

What did you fact-check?: French company produces the first coronavirus drug.
Explanation: There no cure for COVID-19 as of now and the proposed drug has dangerous side effects when used without doctor consultation.

What did you fact-check?: This photo of coffins in Italy is linked to the coronavirus.
Explanation: The photo shows deaths due to the migrant crisis, several years ago.

What did you fact-check?: Qatari Deputy Minister of Health leaves an Interview because of coronavirus
Explanation: " The claim isn't true. While in an interview, the host broke his chair which made the interviewee stand to help him. The video shows this."

What did you fact-check?: Videos showing police raids or army raids against people who don’t respect confinement measures in Algeria or Morocco.
Explanation: The video was shot on March 7th, 2020. It shows the dispersal of an anti-government demonstration by the security forces, with no link with confinement measures or coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Most of the passengers in an Ethiopian airlines flight from Italy are infected with coronavirus.
Explanation: The viral video is from a mock drill from Senegal.

What did you fact-check?: Says imposters in hazmat suits are going door to door in Stockton, California, saying they are checking residents for fever or COVID-19, but they “will enter your home and physically attempt robbery.”
Explanation: Posts around the nation warn people not to open their doors to imposters who say they are doing coronavirus testing but actually want to rob the residents. Like other such claims, this one about an alleged scam in Stockton, Calif., is false, according to police.

What did you fact-check?: Drinking bitter gourd juice cures the coronavirus.
Explanation: There is no proven evidence from any research so far which establishes that bitter gourd juice cures coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: A photo making the rounds on social media claims to show people who have died from the coronavirus in Italy.
Explanation: The coffins in the photo are those of the victims of the Lampedusa maritime tragedy in 2013.

Countries: North Macedonia, Serbia, Bosnia and Herzegovina
What did you fact-check?: A Russian drug called Arbidol, cures coronavirus.
