Explanation: Saint Luke’s Hospital in Kansas City did not issue the letter, according to its staff.

What did you fact-check?: “More people have died from knowing Hillary (Clinton)” than from coronavirus.
Explanation: The claim is false.

What did you fact-check?: A video has been viewed thousands of times in multiple Facebook posts which claims to show the Koran being distributed to people in China after it lifted a “ban” on the Islamic holy text following the outbreak of the novel coronavirus, COVID-19.
Explanation: The claim is false; the video has circulated online since at least 2013 with reports about people receiving copies of the Bible in China.

What did you fact-check?: Graphics or social media cards supposedly from UNICEF contain tips and information on how to prevent and combat the coronavirus outbreak and COVID-19.
Explanation: The graphics and the tips are not from UNICEF

What did you fact-check?: Research by the Saint Luke’s Hospital of Kansas City found that consuming alcoholic beverages may reduce the risk of infection by coronavirus. Vodka was the most recommended drink.
Explanation: The hospital says the claim is false. The WHO does not recommend alcohol consumption to prevent the coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: U.S. hospitals are preparing for 96 million coronavirus infections and nearly half a million deaths, leaked documents reveal.
Explanation: An infectious disease expert presenting to the American Hospital Association estimated there could be as many as 96 million cases of COVID-19 in the U.S. in a year. But there is no indication that hospitals are preparing for an outbreak of that magnitude, as this headline suggests.

What did you fact-check?: An Egyptian writer predicted the new coronavirus six years ago.
Explanation: The Egyptian writer, Dr. Ahmed Khaled Tawfiq, foretold the novel coronavirus in his book "Shorbet Hajj Dawood" in 2014, about the presence of the virus in Egypt. Misbar has verified the news, which is misleading.

What did you fact-check?: Vietnam was the first country to contain and develop a quick test for SARS and COVID-19.
Explanation: The claim that Vietnam was the first country to contain SARS and develop a quick test kit is mostly legitimate. The claim that WHO says it takes four years to develop a test kit appears to be inaccurate.

What did you fact-check?: A video says COVID-19 is caused by 5G.
Explanation: The link between 5G and COVID-19 is not explained in the video and it does not hold any scientific value.

What did you fact-check?: An image has been shared alongside a claim that shows China administering the “world’s first new coronavirus vaccine” after the global outbreak of the novel coronavirus, COVID-19.
Explanation: The photos have circulated in reports about China testing a potential COVID-19 vaccine.

What did you fact-check?: An image has been shared in multiple posts on Facebook and Twitter alongside a claim that it shows China administering the “world’s first new coronavirus vaccine” after the global outbreak of the novel coronavirus, COVID-19.
Explanation: The claim is misleading. The photos have circulated in reports about China testing a potential COVID-19 vaccine.

What did you fact-check?: Former diplomat Henry Kissinger encouraged mandatory vaccination, in order to facilitate radical sanitary measures such as forced sterilization or genetic modification.
Explanation: Those declarations are pure invention

What did you fact-check?: Tanzanian President unmasks false pandemic.
Explanation: The pandemic is real, but the issue of the papaya, the goat and the quail that tested positive for COVID-19 is developing within a political dispute in Tanzania. It cannot be proven to be false or true.

What did you fact-check?: Claim that photos show dogs being killed in China as part of efforts to combat COVID-19.
Explanation: The post is partly false. While there are media reports concerning pets being killed in China because of fears over the spread of COVID-19, they remain unverified and have been denied by authorities. The photos accompanying the post are unrelated to COVID-19. The WHO says there is no evidence that companion animals/pets can be infected with COVID-19 despite a single case in Hong Kong of a dog testing “weak positive."

What did you fact-check?: People who died after being infected by the novel coronavirus can’t receive any mortuary care.
Explanation: The HCSP (Haut conseil de la santé publique) told AFP not all mortuary care is forbidden for victims of the novel coronavirus. Embalming is forbidden but mortuary basic care can still be processed with additional precautions.

What did you fact-check?: Alcohol-based hand sanitizer can influence results in a breathalyzer test.
Explanation: Spreading alcohol-based hand sanitizer does not affect the breathalyzer test.

What did you fact-check?: Chinese President Xi Jinping visited Muslims to understand why they are not contracting COVID-19.
Explanation: The viral video is a combination of three clips of Xi Jinping visiting the northwest region of China in 2016.

What did you fact-check?: Two local celebrities in Argentine are infected with coronavirus
Explanation: The celebrities denied the claim.

What did you fact-check?: A case of coronavirus was confirmed in Cali in Colombia, and a video shows doctors treating patients in a bus station.
Explanation: " The video shows a drill organized by Cali's transportation authority, to prepare in case coronavirus arrives in the city."

What did you fact-check?: A case of coronavirus was confirmed in Sincelejo in Colombia.
Explanation: " There is a possible case in Sincelejo which hasn't been confirmed as of 3/6/20."

What did you fact-check?: Work suspension in Ecuador due to coronavirus since Monday 09/03/2020.
Explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

What did you fact-check?: Work suspension in Ecuador due to coronavirus since Monday 09/03/2020.
Explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

What did you fact-check?: Aaj Tak channel aired a program that said drinking alcohol or smoking weed can cure COVID-19.
Explanation: Aaj Tak channel did not telecast such a program. The photos were taken from a fact-check episode debunking the claim and conclude that neither alcohol nor weed can cure COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: The mayor Of Buffalo told people to evacuate due to the coronavirus outbreak.
Explanation: The mayor denied this claim when he responded to a Facebook post spreading the misinformation.

What did you fact-check?: CDC sponsored Facebook post asking for help with “escaped” coronavirus patient.
Explanation: The post was created by a fake CDC account.

What did you fact-check?: Holding your breath for 10sec can determine if you have COVID-19 and you should drink water every 15 minutes.
Explanation: There are no medical and scientific evidences

What did you fact-check?: Medical Center in El Cachorro (Sevilla) closed due to a possible coronavirus infected person.
Explanation: The claim is false. Emergencies official channel of Sevilla denies it.

What did you fact-check?: Medical report of Hospital General Universitario Santa Lucía de Cartagena (Murcia) from a person with possible coronavirus.
Explanation: The medical report is old, and refers to another kind of coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: It is a designed virus ordered to laboratories by Christine Lagarde when she was in the IMF. She said that “old people live too long and this is a risk for the global economy. We must do something, urgently.”
Explanation: There is no proof Lagarde said this.

What did you fact-check?: Increasing border controls will stop coronavirus from spreading.
Explanation: Neither the WHO nor the CDC estimate that closing borders will stop the coronavirus

What did you fact-check?: Emirates has suspended flights to Johannesburg after South Africa announced its first case of novel coronavirus.
Explanation: The claim is false.

What did you fact-check?: The consumption of pig causes COVID-19 entry into Indonesia.
Explanation: COVID-19 spreads in Indonesia because there are Indonesian citizens who have contact with foreign citizens previously exposed to the coronavirus. Research shows that pigs carry only one virus that can be transmitted to humans, namely the H1N1 virus that causes swine flu.

What did you fact-check?: Turks are not going to be infected by COVID-19 due to their genes.
Explanation: Distribution of the ACE2 protein among nations is not clear. Referred anthropologist was a Nazi and classified people by measuring body parts, not by genetic analysis.

What did you fact-check?: A COVID-19 case has been diagnosed in Yedikule Hospital, Istanbul.
Explanation: The lab report is outdated and shows other mild coronaviruses were found in the case

What did you fact-check?: Girl infected with coronavirus found dead in her apartment in Delhi.
Explanation: The incident in the post does not pertain to a coronavirus case in Delhi but is related to the death of a 22-year-old woman in Tamil Nadu’s Chettipedu.

What did you fact-check?: A television news report about a US biotech company runs alongside a claim that the company successfully created a vaccine for the COVID-19 within “three hours.”
Explanation: The U.S. biotech company said the vaccine requires human testing and will not be available until at least the end of 2020.

What did you fact-check?: Bloggers say Nancy Pelosi delayed coronavirus funding so “Dems could campaign on it.”
Explanation: President Donald Trump signed an $8.3 billion emergency spending bill to address the coronavirus on 3/6/20. There is no evidence House Speaker Nancy Pelosi delayed the bill for political ads.

What did you fact-check?: If the coronavirus gets in your mouth, “drinking water or other liquids will wash them down through your esophagus and into the stomach. Once there, your stomach acid will kill all of the virus.”
Explanation: There is no evidence that drinking water helps to prevent coronavirus infection. Health officials and media outlets have debunked the claim.

What did you fact-check?: “Anybody that wants a test (for the coronavirus) can get a test.”
Explanation: The CDC says health care providers decide whether someone gets tested for coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Pope Francis contacted coronavirus.
Explanation: The Vatican confirms Pope Francis has not contracted coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: WhatsApp message suggests holding your breath for 10 seconds and drinking water every 15 minutes will fight the coronavirus.
Explanation: There is no scientific evidence of this.

What did you fact-check?: Qatar shed Iranian fruits fearing coronavirus.
Explanation: Misbar did not find any official country data on the disposal of Iranian fruit on the market.

What did you fact-check?: China did not apologize to Muslims in a song.
Explanation: This is a fake translation.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus test costs US$3,000 in the U.S.
Explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

What did you fact-check?: WhatsApp message suggests holding your breath for 10 seconds and drinking water every 15 minutes will fight the coronavirus..
Explanation: There is no scientific evidence of this.

What did you fact-check?: 38 % of Americans won’t buy Corona beer due to the coronavirus.
Explanation: " There is nowhere in the study that several media refer to 38 percent of Americans not buying Corona beer. Instead, it says 38 percent of 737 beer-drinking Americans will in no case buy Corona beer, but that doesn't mean it can be generalized to the overall population. There is also no indication that the lack of desire for the Mexican beer is due to coronavirus, as other media also writes. There can be many different explanations that 38 percent of the respondents do not want to buy the beer, for example that they do not like it."

What did you fact-check?: Wuhan sulfur dioxide emission map shows NASA forecast.
Explanation: The map, made with data from NASA, is a forecast of sulfur dioxide and volcanic gas emissions based on archived data, not a current or real-time record of the increase in gas.

What did you fact-check?: Monkeys are stealing food from a hospital in South Africa.
Explanation: The video was taken before the COVID-19 crisis in a different part of the country.

What did you fact-check?: A Shaheen Bagh protest in India was claimed to have coronavirus.
Explanation: Hospitals in Delhi confirmed that no Shaheen Bagh protest had tested positive for COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: Chinese government is killing people who refuse to be evacuated.
Explanation: Video is an edit from four videos taken out of context.

What did you fact-check?: A herbal tea can cure symptoms of coronavirus, even if it is a bioterrorism weapon.
Explanation: This claim is false. A "doctor" in nanotechnology and an antivaccine Venezuelan activist said coronavirus can be cured by electromagnetism and/or herbal tea. He also claimed he cured President Chávez from cancer but then died because he didn\'t follow his treatment.

What did you fact-check?: The test for coronavirus costs US$3,000 in the United States.
Explanation: The only tests approved by FDA and CDC in the U.S. were provided for free. There may be secondary costs such as hospitalization or medical consultation.

What did you fact-check?: Runny nose and coughing sputum are not symptoms of COVID-19.
Explanation: In advisories issued by WHO, "runny nose" and "sputum production" are symptoms of COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: Precautionary measures suggested by UNICEF.
Explanation: The viral message was not issued by UNICEF. Some measures suggested in the message contradict the WHO’S view on COVID-19 and have no scientific evidence.

What did you fact-check?: Medical book states that coronavirus is just a common cold.
Explanation: COVID-19 is more dangerous than the common cold.

What did you fact-check?: Does France underestimate the outbreak?
Explanation: On social networks, many users claim that the number of coronavirus cases in France is underestimated, because there are fewer tests in France than elsewhere. This international comparison is not relevant.

What did you fact-check?: A confidential governmental document proves that the government has decided to postpone local elections in France because of the outbreak.
Explanation: This document is fake. The government did not make this decision.

What did you fact-check?: Donating plasma or blood is free testing for the coronavirus.
Explanation: Currently the test for coronavirus is free.

What did you fact-check?: Novel coronavirus has a 99.7% survival rate.
Explanation: The CDC does not confirm this.

What did you fact-check?: The coronavirus test costs $3,200.
Explanation: Patients will not incur costs when tested by the CDC.

What did you fact-check?: A patent that is being shared to claim COVID-19 is old.
Explanation: The patent is related to SARS, not COVID-19

What did you fact-check?: No work in several regions of Spain due to coronavirus.
Explanation: The link takes you to a picture of a monkey.

What did you fact-check?: 86 clients of a brothel in quarantine after a prostituted tested positive in coronavirus.
Explanation: This claim was a satire shared as real news.

What did you fact-check?: Two Chinese nationals in Kenya have been killed after allegedly escaping from quarantine at the Nairobi Airport.
Explanation: The reports are false.

What did you fact-check?: Every election year has a disease; coronavirus has a contagion factor of 2 and a cure rate of 99.7% for those under 50 it infects.
Explanation: Every year in the U.S. is an election year, if taking into account midterm elections as well as presidential elections, and contrary to the claim, not every election year has had a disease outbreak. The transmissibility of the coronavirus, represented by the “basic reproduction number," is still under study. Currently, the basic reproduction numbers reported for the virus causing COVID-19 range between 2 to more than 6.

What did you fact-check?: The coronavirus outbreak is caused by 5G technology.
Explanation: There is no link between COVID-19 and 5G technology. The cause of the disease is proven to be a novel coronavirus. 5G technology uses low-energy radio waves, which do not damage DNA or cells unlike ionizing radiatio

What did you fact-check?: Shanghai government officially recommends Vitamin C for COVID-19.
Who said/posted it?: Andrew W. Saul, Orthomolecular Medicine News Service
Explanation: Intravenous high-dose Vitamin C has been used to treat patients with COVID-19 in certain Chinese hospitals, but it has not been recommended by the Shanghai government. .

What did you fact-check?: There is an anti-Chinese protest in Italy due to COVID-19.
Explanation: The demonstration was for an anti-Fascist event to commemorate the victim of racism, Valerio Verbano. It was filmed on 2/22/20 in Rome.

What did you fact-check?: UNICEF recommendations
Explanation: The message is misleading and has the potential to cause fear in India.

What did you fact-check?: The WHO has issued an alert against buying holy colors from China
Explanation: " The WHO hasn't issued an advisory against buying Holi colors from coronavirus-hit China."

What did you fact-check?: President Donald Trump tweeted, “Coronavirus vaccine from Israel! Stock market up! Economy even stronger now! Besides US, Israel best at inventions
Explanation: President Donald Trump did not tweet this.

What did you fact-check?: Viral claims propagating UNICEF message about coronavirus.
Explanation: Mr. Jeremy Sprigge, communication specialist for UNICEF Sri Lanka, confirmed that “these messages are not UNICEF statements and henceforth FALSE."

What did you fact-check?: Precautionary measures suggested by UNICEF.
Explanation: The viral message was not issued by UNICEF. Some of the measures have no scientific evidence.

What did you fact-check?: The Success of an Egyptian serum in treating coronavirus.
Explanation: The Egyptian Ministry of Health denies that China has officially announced the success of the Egyptian serum to cure COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: Crown Prince of Abu Dhabi Mohammed bin Zayed is infected with coronavirus.
Explanation: " There is no official news about bin Zayed's infection with the virus."

What did you fact-check?: Four cases of coronavirus were reported in the West Bank.
Explanation: Four cases of COVID-19 were recorded among tourists in Beit Jala in the West Bank. Ma\'an News Agency modified the facts with other news entitled "Coronavirus In Bethlehem and the Ministry of Health is Calling For Calm and Waiting For Instructions."

What did you fact-check?: In Kuwait, he sneezed during Friday sermon, and the worshipers expelled him.
Explanation: The video is old and was circulationing before the appearance of the virus.

Countries: North Macedonia, Croatia, Bosnia and Herzegovina
What did you fact-check?: The vaccine against the new coronavirus was created before the disease appeared; three people who recently arrived from China in Sarajevo Canton are under medical supervision and have brought COVID-19 to Sarajevo.
Explanation: The British National Health System and the WHO report there is no vaccine yet for COVID-19. As of 3/5/20, there was no confirmation of a coronavirus positive finding in the three patients, and for several days thereafter results were found to be negative.

What did you fact-check?: 80 clients of a brothel were put on quarantine due to coronavirus.
Explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

What did you fact-check?: A post says that there is a movie that predicted the pandemic and it’s called “Coronavirus”.
Explanation: The image is false, is manipulated and it uses the cover of the movie “The flu” with the wrong title. There’s no movie called “Coronavirus”.

What did you fact-check?: Article says that the Vatican confirmed that the Pope and two assistants have coronavirus.
Explanation: There’s no official statement from the Vatican saying that Pope Francis is infected with COVID-19. Pope has felt ill, but not with the coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: NHK World’s Chinese language service calls COVID-19 the “Novel Japanese Coronavirus”.
Explanation: What was said on NHK World in Chinese was “a summary of the novel coronavirus infection situation in Japan”, this was mistranslated by some in Japan as "Novel Japanese coronavirus".

What did you fact-check?: An image from The Simpsons predicted the novel coronavirus.
Explanation: The claim is false because the montage features shots from two different episodes, one of which has been digitally altered to include the words “corona virus”.

What did you fact-check?: Photos show a well-stocked vegan shelf while other items are cleared out.
Explanation: Circulated online since September 2017, the photo shows panic buying after Hurricane Harvey in the U.S.

What did you fact-check?: UNICEF releases coronavirus prevention guidelines.
Explanation: " UNICEF has not released an advisory; many of the claims are contrary to health experts' advice."

What did you fact-check?: This video shows panic buying in the United States, during the coronavirus outbreak
Explanation: The video has circulated online since November 2019, weeks before the novel coronavirus was first detected in the Chinese city of Wuhan.

What did you fact-check?: This is a photo of the first Moroccan infected with the virus.
Explanation: The photo is from an advertisement for an opthamologist clinic in Algeria.

What did you fact-check?: COVID-19 was created in 2014 by an English institute.
Explanation: A viral video denounces that the Pirbright Institute of the United Kingdom, created the virus that causes COVID-19. The institute denied the rumors, noting that the virus strain they work with to make a vaccine is different from the new coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: The first dog was infected with coronavirus.
Explanation: " A dog in Hong Kong was tested weakly positive for coronavirus but didn't show any symptoms so far."

What did you fact-check?: Israel creates a vaccine for the coronavirus.
Explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

What did you fact-check?: Dr. Lupita Yamamoto has found a vaccine that destroys the coronavirus.
Explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

What did you fact-check?: First policeman infected with coronavirus in Ecuador.
Explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

What did you fact-check?: 10 coronavirus cases confirmed in Ecuador.
Explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

What did you fact-check?: First policeman infected with coronavirus in Ecuador.
Explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

What did you fact-check?: The Simpsons predicted the coronavirus pandemic years ago.
Explanation: Other than the "Osaka Flu" infecting many residents of Springfield, the events of the 1993 episode "Marge in Chains" have no similarities with the COVID-19 pandemic.

What did you fact-check?: The common cold is the only type of coronavirus.
Explanation: Coronaviruses can cause different illnesses in animals and humans, including the common cold. However, they can also lead to severe diseases such as Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) and Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS).

What did you fact-check?: Officials say coronavirus killed 200 in Iran.
Explanation: The number of deaths in official reports as of 3/3/20 were lower than stated in this article.

What did you fact-check?: New coronavirus was registered in 2018.
Explanation: " It was another type of coronavirus that doesn't affect humans."

What did you fact-check?: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi
Explanation: " According to Narendra Modi's official social media account and Indian media, Modi did not make such a statement."

What did you fact-check?: Lonely Ka’bah from Tawaf after Saudi Arabia makes policy on coronavirus.
Explanation: " Activities around the Ka'bah located in the Grand Mosque, Mecca, proceed as usual as of 3/4/20."

What did you fact-check?: Masks from Wet Wipes effectively prevent coronavirus transmission
Explanation: Wet tissue material makes dust, dirt and bacteria stick more easily.

What did you fact-check?: Videograph shows COVID-19 is more dangerous than former outbreaks.
Explanation: The video is cut at the beginning and the end. The whole video shows COVID-19 is not as dangerous as the former outbreaks or other causes of death.

What did you fact-check?: Cow dung and cow urine can cure coronavirus.
Explanation: Dr Sumit Ray, a Senior Consultant, Critical Care Medicine, said that there are no scientific studies to support these claims.

What did you fact-check?: Consuming large doses of Vitamin C can stop the spread of coronavirus.
Explanation: There is no evidence that consuming large doses of Vitamin C cannot stop the spread of coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: “Man visited Albany, N.Y., days before dying from coronavirus.”
Explanation: The image was manipulated to look like it is from ABC News. There is no evidence one of those individuals who died from COVID-19 had recently been to Albany, N.Y.

What did you fact-check?: “The State of Florida has announced measures that all workplaces with 10 employees or more are to have paid mandatory leave to avoid the spread of COVID-19 coronavirus starting on March 6, 2020. All schools are to close for 2 weeks also from March 6.”
Explanation: As of 3/5/20, Florida is not shutting down schools and businesses for two weeks.

What did you fact-check?: The media “pulled down an entire shelf of goods so that they can present the news of people buying stuff in a hysteria over the coronavirus.”
Explanation: An image claims to show a news reporter staging a shot of empty grocery store shelves. The photo is a hoax from Romania.

What did you fact-check?: “The Obama administration made a decision on testing that turned out to be very detrimental to what we’re doing” on the coronavirus.
Explanation: The “decision” Trump talks about had its roots in a 2004 law, when George W. Bush was president. The FDA’s policy pre-dated the Obama administration.

What did you fact-check?: The Obama administration “didn’t do anything about” swine flu.
Explanation: The Obama administration responded with two emergency declarations, triggering billions in spending and other public health responses.

What did you fact-check?: “With regard to the cost, let me be very clear
Explanation: Pence’s claim over simplifies what is involved in making this coverage assurance because a large swath of private health insurance falls beyond these categories. His statement fails to acknowledge the need for action at the state level and from the private sector.

What did you fact-check?: Vitamin C and warm water with lemon can prevent COVID-19.
Explanation: Vitamin C and warm water with lemon have no known effect on the novel coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: European Health Organization (EHO) announced that eating beef can cure coronavirus.
Explanation: There is no official institution with the name European Health Organization (EHO). Also, no authority in the European Union has announced that eating beef will cure coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Garlic, onions and other traditional medicine recipes are treatments against the new coronavirus.
Who said/posted it?: Secretary of the National Security and Defense Council Oleksiy Danilov
Explanation: There is no evidence that garlic or traditional medicine can protect from the new coronavirus, according to the WHO.

What did you fact-check?: Prince of Qatar is infected with coronavirus.
Explanation: The Emir of Qatar has been bedridden for several days, and his temperature is high, indicating that he has COVID-19. But the claim is false.

What did you fact-check?: A fabricated circular for the Lebanese Ministry of Education regarding the end of the school year.
Explanation: The Lebanese Ministry of Education and Higher Education has announced the end of the school year for all different levels of education, after the outbreak of COVID-19 and the appearance of several cases. The circular is false.

What did you fact-check?: Gaza Strip Is coronavirus-free.
Explanation: 17 cases of COVID-19 in the Gaza Strip as of 3/4/20.

What did you fact-check?: Rapper Eminem contacted coronavirus.
Explanation: The post is a hoax.

What did you fact-check?: The coronavirus is a bioweapon by the USA, says German politician Wolfgang Gedeon in a Parliament speech.
Explanation: International scientists, the WHO and German Robert Koch Institute see strong evidence that the coronavirus is of natural origin and its outbreak is related to bats.

What did you fact-check?: Trump’s effort to blame Obama for sluggish coronavirus testing.
Explanation: There was no “Obama rule,” just draft guidance that never took effect and was withdrawn before President Trump took office.

What did you fact-check?: The media group Globo published a photo of the dead of the Lampedusa shipwreck as if they were COVID-19 victims.
Explanation: The image shows coffins of immigrants killed in the tragedy on the island of Lampedusa in 2013, but Aos Fatos found no evidence that the Globo group used the record outside its original context. G1, a site that belongs to Globo, denied misinformation that circulated in March and attributed the same image of coffins to the pandemic.

What did you fact-check?: The first coronavirus case in North Macedonia was a well-known fashion designer.
Explanation: Due to the mass dissemination of the misinformation, Pandeva (the designer) addressed the public through a video message posted on her Facebook profile and denied that she was ill.

What did you fact-check?: Colombia closes its borders to Ecuadorians.
Explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

What did you fact-check?: Israel creates a vaccine for the coronavirus.
Explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

What did you fact-check?: Dr. Lupita Yamamoto has found a vaccine that destroys the coronavirus.
Explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

What did you fact-check?: First coronavirus case in Ambato, Ecuador.
Explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

What did you fact-check?: 10 coronavirus cases are confirmed in Ecuador.
Explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

What did you fact-check?: First policeman infected with coronavirus in Ecuador.
Explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

What did you fact-check?: Vitamin C prevents coronavirus.
Explanation: Researchers reject that there should be any evidence to suggest that vitamin C intake can prevent COVID-19. With a healthy level of vitamin C, you can shorten a cold, but that does not mean that you can prevent or treat COVID-19 by consuming large amounts of vitamin C.

What did you fact-check?: China names COVID-19 the ”Japanese pneumonia”.
Explanation: This is a widespread mistranslation of a sentence in a Chinese report that read "日本新型冠状病毒肺炎疫情不断变化" and which means "the situation with infections of the novel coronavirus in Japan is constantly in flux."

What did you fact-check?: A dog was quarantined in Hong Kong after testing positive for the new coronavirus.
Explanation: The information from the first case of the new coronavirus detected in a dog is true. On the other hand, there is a canine coronavirus that is different from the one that began to be detected in Wuha

What did you fact-check?: Drinking sips of water prevents the new coronavirus.
Explanation: WHO maintains that there is no evidence of this and specialists consulted by AFP explain that the virus is only detected with a laboratory test and that drinking water does not "wash" it.

What did you fact-check?: People queue outside an Aldi supermarket in Germany to buy food in fear of the new coronavirus.
Explanation: The 2011 video shows the opening of an Aldi store.

What did you fact-check?: Ads are selling masks protecting against COVID-19.
Explanation: " U.S. authorities don't recommend wearing masks and the doctor does not speak about COVID-19."

What did you fact-check?: Multiple allegations on how to protect oneself from the new coronavirus.
Explanation: Many of the practices detailed in the post are misleading and inaccurate.

What did you fact-check?: Multiple allegations on how to protect oneself from CoV.
Explanation: Many of the practices detailed in the post are misleading and inaccurate.

What did you fact-check?: A man is hospitalized after eating a bat.
Explanation: This photo that has circulated in an online fundraising page features a man with a lung condition unrelated to the novel coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Russia said COVID-19 is man-made.
Explanation: The Russian Ministry of Health denies making such a statement; the document states COVID-19 is a “recombinant virus” which can form naturally.

What did you fact-check?: The coronavirus has been discovered in poultry.
Explanation: Sri Lankan authorities said the coronavirus has not been discovered in poultry. The photos were taken from various unrelated reports online and show chickens sickened with other diseases.

What did you fact-check?: A Nigerian taxi driver threatens to spread COVID-19.
Explanation: The claim originated from a parody account and has been denied by the man pictured and by government officials.

What did you fact-check?: The photos show Indians bathing in cow dung to prevent infection.
Explanation: The photos show participants at an annual cow dung festival held in the southern region of India in October 2019, several weeks before COVID-19 was first detected in the Chinese city of Wuhan.

What did you fact-check?: Video shows Wuhan residents lining up for death certificates.
Explanation: The video previously circulated in reports about Wuhan residents gathering to collect free vegetables.

What did you fact-check?: There is a case of coronavirus at the School of Architects of Madrid.
Explanation: The event depicted was an exercise.

What did you fact-check?: Chinese official detainted a CoV case.
Explanation: It was an exercise.

What did you fact-check?: Claims that drinking boiled garlic water cures novel coronavirus.
Explanation: Medical experts told AFP there was no evidence to support the theory about drinking garlic water; international health organisations do not recommend the remedy and have said there is no specific antiviral treatment for the new strain of the novel coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: The Simpsons predicted the coronavirus outbreak.
Explanation: The frames were taken from different episodes, about the Osaka flu and the housecat flu. One of them was digitally manipulated to include the word "coronavirus."

What did you fact-check?: Vinegar is more effective than alcohol-based hand sanitizers for killing the novel coronavirus.
Explanation: Vinegar is not effective as a hand sanitizer. Its effects on breaking up the fat protection around viruses are very limited. Alcohol and soap are very effective as protection.

What did you fact-check?: Drinking hot water prevents the COVID-19
Explanation: This information is false. Health authorities do not recognize hot water as a preventive measure and experts point out that it could be counterproductive.

What did you fact-check?: A health expert surmises that the new coronavirus might not spread in Nigeria because of the hot temperature.
Explanation: Warmer air holds more moisture, preventing airborne viruses from traveling as far as they would in dry air. But it is not confirmed if the new coronavirus is vulnerable to hot temperature.

What did you fact-check?: Ecuadorean doctor develops a vaccine for COVID-19.
Explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

What did you fact-check?: Two cases of coronavirus have been reported in Loja, in Ecuador.
Explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

What did you fact-check?: Azuay Governor in Ecuador seeks the cure of covid-19 in indigenous medicine.
Explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

What did you fact-check?: A new case of coronavirus has been confirmed in Tulcán, Ecuador.
Explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

What did you fact-check?: This video was supposedly developed by the Ecuadorian Health Ministry to encourage people to wash their hands constantly.
Explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

What did you fact-check?: A brothel in Spain was under quarantine.
Explanation: The claim is from the satirical website Cerebrother.

What did you fact-check?: An image shows Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer criticizing President Trump’s restrictions on foreign nationals traveling to the U.S. from China.
Explanation: The tweet was fake.

What did you fact-check?: The government — or specific states such as Michigan or Florida — has mandated that employers and schools close for two weeks.
Explanation: No such announcement has been made.

What did you fact-check?: Pope Francis and his two aides have been infected with the new coronavirus
Explanation: The pope tested negative.

What did you fact-check?: The CDC recommends men shave their beards to be protected against the new coronavirus.
Explanation: A 2017 CDC infographic shows how facial hair could interfere with respirator masks. The graphic is unrelated to coronavirus protection and the CDC has not recommended people should shave their beards to ward off the virus.

What did you fact-check?: A bovine vaccine can be used to inoculate people against coronavirus.
Explanation: There is no approved coronavirus vaccine.

What did you fact-check?: Patents mean deadly diseases and viruses were created or invented in a lab.
Explanation: The patents are for possible treatments or vaccines, some of which were tested but did not work.

What did you fact-check?: You can’t get infected by kissing the hands of a virgin or saint statue.
Explanation: Kissing the hands of a virgin or saint statue is a tradition of the Holy Week in some parts of Spain, but it is not free from viruses and therefore can be a way of infection.

What did you fact-check?: An audio clip claims Kenya has recorded 63 cases of COVID-19.
Explanation: The audio clip was edited and taken out of context. It was part of a training exercise by the Ministry of Health to prepare for a likely outbreak ahead of the opening of a quarantine center in Nairobi.

What did you fact-check?: Pope Francis and two of his aides have been infected with COVID-19.
Explanation: The Vatican and the embassy said the pope recently fell ill with a common cold.

What did you fact-check?: Japanese Asahi Shimbun TV
Explanation: " The original news clip suggested that there could be some COVID-19 cases being misdiagnosed as flu in the U.S. But it didn't mention that COVID-19 originated in the U.S."

What did you fact-check?: A study published by two Chinese research institutions suggest that human semen can cure COVID-19.
Explanation: The screenshot of the report circulated online was digitally manipulated. The original report suggested another medicine could be the cure, not human semen.

What did you fact-check?: Spices can ward off the new coronavirus.
Explanation: Spices can increase endurance but there is no evidence that they can prevent or cure coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus can be transmitted through imported goods
Explanation: The virus cannot live outside the human body for a long time.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus dies in temperatures 26-27C and when exposed to sunlight.
Explanation: There are no studies to support this claim.

What did you fact-check?: Turkish raki prevents COVID-19.
Explanation: The video clip was doctored. There is no evidence that shows raki prevents the disease.

What did you fact-check?: Bloggers say the Vatican reports that Pope Francis tested negative for the coronavirus before a second test came back positive.
Explanation: An Italian newspaper reported that Pope Francis tested negative for the coronavirus. The Vatican has not confirmed or denied the report.

What did you fact-check?: Video shows President Donald Trump saying COVID-19 is the Democrats’ “new hoax.”
Explanation: The video makes it look like Trump called coronavirus “their new hoax.” There was nearly a full minute between when the president said “coronavirus” and “hoax” during a 2/28/20 rally in North Charleston, S.C.

What did you fact-check?: Drink (warm) water or gargle every 15 minutes to rinse the new coronavirus down.
Explanation: There is no scientific evidence that drinking warm water can prevent the new coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Images of BJP men smearing cow dung on one another after their party leader Suman Haripriya said cow dung may help cure coronavirus.
Explanation: Assam BJP MLA Suman Haripriya made those statements on 3/2/20. But the images are from the Goraihabba festival celebrated in Thalavadi (Tamil Nadu) on 10/30/19.

What did you fact-check?: UNICEF circular on coronavirus prevention.
Explanation: Misbar checked the educational bulletin attributed to UNICEF and found it to be false, and completely different from the original bulletin found on the official website of the organization.

What did you fact-check?: Vitamin C can cure COVID-19.
Explanation: The claim is not based on medical evidence.

What did you fact-check?: This video shows dead coronavirus victims amassed in the Bergamo (or Brescia) hospital.
Explanation: The video was recorded in Ecuador at the Los Ceibos General Hospital in Guayaquil.

What did you fact-check?: Ecuadorian doctor develops a vaccine for COVID-19.
Explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

What did you fact-check?: Two cases of coronavirus have been reported in Loja, Ecuador.
Explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

What did you fact-check?: Azuay governor in Ecuador seeks the cure of COVID-19 in indigenous medicine.
Explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

What did you fact-check?: Video claims that “The health system is collapsing” in North Macedonia.
Explanation: A false claim in the video 4/3/20 is that Macedonia has by far the lowest number of tested compared to other countries. Data for 4/4/20 shows Macedonia is the second country in the region in terms of the number of tests conducted for COVID-19 per million inhabitants. Another false claim is that the number of cases per capita is the highest in Macedonia from the entire region, but as of 4/7/20, the number of cases per capita in Macedonia is somewhere in the middle compared to the whole region.

What did you fact-check?: Uganda has recorded its first coronavirus case from Chinese nationals at the Entebbe Regional Referral Hospital.
Explanation: As of Mar 3rd, Uganda’s Minister of Health, Dr Jane Ruth Aceng,stated that they were all tested negative, and that Uganda is yet to record a COVID-19 case.

What did you fact-check?: Shave your beard to protect yourself from the new coronavirus.
Explanation: US health authorities did not recommend shaving your beard to protect yourself from the new coronavirus; At no time do they refer to the need to shave facial hair.

What did you fact-check?: Outbreak of COVID-19 is a worldwide fake. The fatality rate is too low for an epidemic. The WHO admitted causing the SARS outbreak in 2003.
Explanation: There are thousands of confirmed cases around the globe. The virus is confirmed in multiple labs. The fatality rate is greater than that of some of pandemics in the 20th century.

What did you fact-check?: This photo shows a brothel in Europe where people have been quarantined.
Explanation: The claim originated on a satirical website based in Spain. The photo is of a nightclub in Marbella.

What did you fact-check?: These are seven “evil” things COVID-19 is “afraid” of.
Explanation: The claim is misleading; health experts say such practices are only effective when applied properly and can be harmful if used incorrectly.

What did you fact-check?: A runny nose and sputum secretion are not symptoms of novel coronavirus.
Explanation: The WHO listed these as possible symptoms.

What did you fact-check?: Israeli scientists have developed a COVID-19 vaccine.
Explanation: " Israel's Migal Institute said it was still working to develop a vaccine. The photo is from a stock photo website."

What did you fact-check?: 12 pieces of advice for coronavirus, including symptoms, transmission, how to neutralize the virus.
Explanation: Most of the advice is false or unfounded.

What did you fact-check?: Plant-based cure for coronavirus discovered in Iran.
Explanation: The plant-based product has not been approved or submitted for approval to Iranian authorities, according to the official news agency.

What did you fact-check?: Disinfectant gel causes cancer.
Explanation: There have been no credible studies to prove this, according to health experts.

What did you fact-check?: Twitter users said Adutwumwaa Bitters cure coronavirus.
Explanation: Producers of the medicine, Adutwumwaa Herbal Industries Limited, have stated that their product does not cure coronavirus. The WHO says there’s no cure, vaccine or antiviral medicine to prevent or treat coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Constant sex kills coronavirus.
Explanation: Sex cannot kill or cure coronavirus. But close contact with an infected person will expose the partner to the disease.

What did you fact-check?: Viral photo in Nigeria suggests former President Obasanjo said there is no coronavirus in Nigeria and that the minister of health lied.
Explanation: President Obasanjo\'s spokesperson, Kehinde Akinyemi, refuted allegations attributed to Baba; a moniker often used to describe the former head of state. A Google reverse image search revealed that the "Fox News writer" (the source) used the image out of context.

What did you fact-check?: Ecuadorean youtuber Raùl Alvarez Guene supposedly infected with COVID-19.
Explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

What did you fact-check?: Ministry of Health confirms new case of coronavirus in Santa Elena province, Ecuador.
Explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

What did you fact-check?: There are cases of coronavirus in the Amazon forest.
Explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

What did you fact-check?: Local hospital in Ecuador says first covid patient didn’t have coronavirus.
Explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

What did you fact-check?: A bovine coronavirus vaccine, for cattle, is proof that the novel coronavirus isn’t “new” and is evidence of “how much the media controls people.”
Explanation: The cattle vaccine has nothing to do with the COVID-19 virus.

What did you fact-check?: Journalist claims a coronavirus patient was murdered.
Explanation: The tweet did go out from a TV reporter, but was doctored to claim that a murder investigation was underway at the nursing home.

What did you fact-check?: U.S. Vice President Pence urged people with coronavirus to go to the police.
Explanation: This claim is false; Pence never said this.

What did you fact-check?: The Ministry of Health in Spain issues advice about the coronavirus outbreak.
Explanation: The Ministry of Health has not issued an alert.

What did you fact-check?: 3.000 people from Elche (Spain) are infected with the coronavirus after coming back from Milan’s international footwear industry fair.
Explanation: As of 3/2/20, there are no coronavirus cases in Elche; the Ministry of Health has not released a statement claiming any cases.

What did you fact-check?: The pope has COVID-19.
Explanation: The Vatican press office announced the pope has a common cold and is continuing his schedule.

What did you fact-check?: Whatsapp message contains multiple health advises.
Explanation: The text message is based on advice lacking scientific evidence. The WHO does not confirm any of them.

What did you fact-check?: Man critical with novel coronavirus in Barhalganj, India.
Explanation: There is no confirmed case of the novel coronavirus in Barhalganj, a town in Gorakhpur, Uttar Pradesh.The man did not get infected with coronavirus in Barhalganj by consuming chicken.

What did you fact-check?: Alcohol kills the coronavirus.
Explanation: The claim is fake.

What did you fact-check?: Ambulance health care workers are transporting a coronavirus patient in The Hague (The Netherlands), dressed in white protective suits.
Explanation: Medical personnel and news websites had already stated this patiënt was not infected with the coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Post says “sanitizer will do nothing for the coronavirus.”
Explanation: Although they are not effective against all viruses, hand sanitizers with high alcohol content have proven effective against human coronaviruses.

What did you fact-check?: Post says two patients at Valley Regional Medical Center in Brownsville, Texas, “are being looked at” for possible coronavirus infections.
Explanation: Health officials say there are no coronavirus patients in the Rio Grande Valley as of 3/3/20.

What did you fact-check?: The United States is “actually screening fewer people (for the coronavirus than other countries) because we don’t have appropriate testing.”
Explanation: The CDC has stopped publicly reporting the number of tests it’s administered. As of March 4, the United States has lagged behind other nations in terms of coronavirus testing.

What did you fact-check?: U.S. Senator Lindsey Graham says President Trump “probably knows more about medicine and specifically viruses than any of the so-called scientists at the NIH and CDC.”
Explanation: Senator Lindsey Graham did not say this.The quote was fabricated by a Twitter account that has posted fake statements in the past.

What did you fact-check?: “Coronavirus hoax
Explanation: No credible evidence shows the current coronavirus spreading around the world was fabricated.

What did you fact-check?: Multiple videos claim garlic and onions can prevent and cure infection from the novel coronavirus.
Explanation: This claim is false. The WHO says garlic cannot prevent or treat COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: Images show the Great Mosque of Mecca empty.
Explanation: The images are fabricated.

What did you fact-check?: Notice for preparing emergency drugs was released on social media for alumni of Seoul National University College of Medicine.
Explanation: This did not happen.

What did you fact-check?: In North Korea, a person was allegedly shot by local authorities when he violated the quarantine rule and went to a public restroom.
Explanation: Due to complete state control of information and news in North Korea, claims about COVID-19 cannot be verified. This claim is not confirmed.

What did you fact-check?: Ecuadorian youtuber Raùl Alvarez Guene was supposedly infected with COVID-19.
Explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

What did you fact-check?: There are cases of coronavirus in the Amazon forest.
Explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

What did you fact-check?: Local hospital in Ecuador says first COVID-19 patient didn’t have coronavirus.
Explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

What did you fact-check?: With the spread of the new coronavirus, information spread that the government had been producing masks with a Japanese flag in response to the lack of masks.
Explanation: This mask was launched in 2015. The Ministry of Health and the manufacturer denied the fact.

What did you fact-check?: Indonesia has provided 1,000 free tickets for nationals to return home from abroad.
Explanation: The Foreign Ministry dismissed the reports as a hoax.

What did you fact-check?: This is a video of panicked shoppers storming a supermarket amid the coronavirus pandemic.
Explanation: The claim is false; the video was filmed in Germany in 2011, nearly a decade before the coronavirus pandemic broke out.

What did you fact-check?: Four patients infected with the coronavirus are hospitalized in Sri Lanka.
Explanation: Only two suspected patients were hospitalized and both later tested negative.

What did you fact-check?: Classes in Ecuador are suspended because of coronavirus.
Explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

What did you fact-check?: There is a new case of coronavirus in Latacunga, Ecuador.
Explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

What did you fact-check?: Pope Francis and two aides tested positive for coronavirus.
Explanation: The Vatican does not confirm this.

What did you fact-check?: An alkaline diet can prevent coronavirus infection.
Explanation: No food or diet, alkaline or otherwise, can prevent the infectio

What did you fact-check?: Facemasks prevent coronavirus infection.
Explanation: Health authorities do not recommend using a face mask unless there is direct contact with a positive diagnosis.

What did you fact-check?: “Florida hospital reports a coronavirus ‘infestation’ with multiple confirmed patients.”
Explanation: The U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention presumptively confirmed two cases of the 2019 coronavirus in Florida.

What did you fact-check?: Photo shows a man wearing a “government issued Saint Laurent hazardous materials suit.”
Explanation: The image was posted by a self-described parody account.

What did you fact-check?: “Shands Hospital of Gainesville, Florida, has confirmed its first case of coronavirus.”
Explanation: As of 3/2/20, the CDC has confirmed two cases of COVID-19 in Florida. Shands Hospital in Gainesville  has not confirmed a coronavirus case.

What did you fact-check?: Post says no one has died from the coronavirus in the United States.
Explanation: As of 3/3/20, nine people have died from the coronavirus in the United States. The first death was on 3/1/20.

What did you fact-check?: The coronavirus is “simply the common cold.”
Explanation: The 2019 coronavirus is part of a family of viruses that produce illnesses ranging from the common cold to more critical diseases such as SARS or MERS. It is a new virus not previously identified.

What did you fact-check?: This video was shot in a mall in Germany during the coronavirus pandemic.
Explanation: The video was filmed years before the pandemic.

What did you fact-check?: The Vatican confirms Pope Francis was infected with coronavirus.
Explanation: The claim was denied by the Vatican.

What did you fact-check?: The coronavirus Is spreading in Egyptian schools.
Explanation: Misbar found the video shows a poisoning incident at the Technical Secondary School for Girls in Sherbin City, Dakahlia Governorate, north of Cairo.

What did you fact-check?: Beware of Yellow Rain (Agent Orange) coming with a storm from China. It brings chemicals and the coronavirus.
Explanation: " Yellow Rain is not a real rain, it's how to call an chemical weapon in the past. Even a storm is coming, it's unable to bring virus from China to Thailand."

What did you fact-check?: Bill Gates is working on an electronic chip to implant under human skin in order to locate and control people.
Explanation: This is a common conspiracy theory, but Bill Gates never claimed working on this kind of project.

What did you fact-check?: Oklahoma police planning to set up roadblocks to enforce a mandatory COVID-19 vaccination law and slap micro-chipped bracelets on people.
Explanation: A video featuring conspiracy blogger Greg Evensen is showing a speech from 2009.

What did you fact-check?: Photo of Iranian officials visiting the vice president after she contracted COVID-19.
Explanation: " The photo has circulated since 2014, after one of Iran's vice presidents was injured in a traffic accident."

What did you fact-check?: Vatican says Pope Francis has been infected with the novel coronavirus.
Explanation: The Vatican said the pope recently fell ill with a common cold..

What did you fact-check?: 14 points of expert advice about coronavirus, including symptoms, prevention and how it spreads.
Explanation: Research does not support the claims.

What did you fact-check?: Mongolia donates 30,000 sheep to China during the coronavirus epidemic.
Explanation: The videos circulated before Mongolia announced the donation on 2/27/20.

What did you fact-check?: Volcanic ash can kill the coronavirus.
Explanation: The WHO says there is no evidence of this.

What did you fact-check?: Germany gave medical protection equipment like masks to China, now it’s missing in Germany.
Explanation: Germany sent protection equipment to China twice in February.

What did you fact-check?: The coronavirus is more dangerous for animals than for humans.
Explanation: There is no proof that animals can get or spread the new coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: A video shows people storming an Aldi supermarket to buy groceries because of coronavirus fear.
Explanation: The video was made in 2011 and shows people eager to buy laptops at an Aldi store in Kiel.

What did you fact-check?: This virus must be old because the label on a bottle of disinfectant from 2015 shows “coronavirus“.
Explanation: The coronavirus family is known for decades, so older disinfectants  display its name.

What did you fact-check?: Local news channel in Ecuador confirms more people are infected with coronavirus.
Explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

What did you fact-check?: Health Ministry in Ecuador confirms three new cases of coronavirus.
Explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

What did you fact-check?: Pope Francis is infected with coronavirus.
Explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

What did you fact-check?: Drinking warm water or tea can prevent contagions.
Explanation: Studies do not prove coronavirus is affected by temperature and or inanimate objects.

What did you fact-check?: Doctors recommend carbon filter face masks to prevent coronavirus spread.
Explanation: Video claim is false. The FDA and CDC concluded they are not effective for children and are not recommended for home use. The videos are used to sell the masks to people concerned about the coronavirus outbreak.

What did you fact-check?: Garlic water can treat coronavirus.
Explanation: The WHO says there is no evidence to confirm this claim.

What did you fact-check?: Pangolin is the original cause of COVID-19.
Explanation: The information from scientists who first pointed to pangolin as the cause of the infection has been corrected.

What did you fact-check?: Russia announces the closure of airspace and suspends all incoming and outgoing flights to China.
Explanation: The Russian government had imposed a temporary and partial ban on the movement of Chinese nationals. All Russian airlines, with the exception of national airline Aeroflot, stopped flying to China on 1/31/20. Ikar airline will continue flights between Moscow and China. All planes arriving from China will be sent to a separate terminal in the Moscow Sheremetyevo airport. Aeroflot reduced the frequency of flights to Beijing, Shanghai, and Guangzhou until 2/29/20.

What did you fact-check?: Taiwanese president and former president were infected. The former president died.
Explanation: The images of screenshots and official documents are doctored or forged. President Tsai made a public speech at a 2/28/20 memorial event.

What did you fact-check?: Police in China have killed 25,000 COVID-19 patients so far.
Explanation: None of the four clips spliced together shows cops “shooting” COVID-19 patients. One is of a road crash; another features not gunshots, but the explosion of Lunar New Year fireworks in the background.

What did you fact-check?: COVID-19 came from Chinese people eating human babies, in an effort to improve their skin.
Explanation: The claim is false and baseless. The photos are a decade old; some show a Chinese man "eating babies" as protest art in 2000.

What did you fact-check?: A video says the Vatican confirmed Pope Francis and two aides tested positive for coronavirus.
Explanation: The Vatican has denied the report, saying the pope has a “slight illness.”

What did you fact-check?: President Barack Obama “waited six months to call swine flu an emergency after thousands died.”
Explanation: The Obama administration declared swine flu, or H1N1, a public health emergency six weeks before H1N1 was declared a pandemic. No H1N1 deaths had yet been recorded in the United States.

What did you fact-check?: The Vatican confirmed that Pope Francis and two aides tested positive for coronavirus.
Explanation: The Vatican denied allegations that Pope Francis contracted COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: CDC recommends men shave their beards to be protected against the new coronavirus.
Explanation: The claim is based on a CDC chart created in 2017 to advise medical workers on the best practices for wearing a "filtering facepiece respirator" during contact with viral patients. It was not intended for the general public - nor specifically for preventing the spread of the coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Pope Francis was diagnosed with coronavirus.
Explanation: The pontiff tested negative for COVID-19 after showing flu symptoms.

What did you fact-check?: A video shows a man with COVID-19 spitting on grocery store items.
Explanation: Tracing back to the earliest copy of the video online, there is no information that the person is positive for COVID-19. The blurry clip likewise makes it difficult to determine what the person was doing to the grocery items.

What did you fact-check?: A video of chaos in a shop claims people are panicking after the first confirmed case of coronavirus in Lithuania.
Explanation: The video was made in May 2018 in Romania, during a sale at a supermarket.

What did you fact-check?: Doctors in Japan advise people to drink water every 15 minutes to prevent an infection.
Explanation: The WHO says drinking water does not prevent novel coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Vitamin helps against COVID-19.
Explanation: Health experts told AFP there is insufficient evidence for this claim.

What did you fact-check?: Election years in the United States coincide with major disease outbreaks.
Explanation: Several years of discovery or the associated spread of a disease do not match election years, national and international health organizations said.

What did you fact-check?: The Cambodian prime minister has COVID-19.
Explanation: The photo is from 2017; the prime minister was treated for something else.

What did you fact-check?: Beef meat is the best vaccine against COVID-19.
Explanation: There is no evidence to prove this.

What did you fact-check?: Tips against coronavirus like holding your breath and drinking water.
Explanation: " These tips don't prevent infection with coronavirus."

What did you fact-check?: Shaving facial hair ensures safety from COVID-19, further attributing the message to the CDC.
Explanation: This information was directed to workers who use respirators in carrying out their tasks and has nothing to do with preventing the spread of coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Video of a roof full of bats claims it is the source of coronavirus.
Explanation: The video was recorded in Florida in 2011, not in China.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus patients in China are caught by officials on a highway.
Explanation: The video shows a mock drill. The China SWAT team in the video is "practicing" how to deal with coronavirus patients.

What did you fact-check?: Chinese police use a fishing net to arrest a man with a high fever.
Explanation: The video shows a police training exercise.

What did you fact-check?: Florida man is arrested for robbery using cough as a weapon.
Explanation: The photo was created using a prank generator site.

What did you fact-check?: Summer temperatures will make coronavirus disappear.
Explanation: Not enough is known about the coronavirus to prove this claim.

What did you fact-check?: “Spanish newspaper ABC reports there are two possible COVID-19 cases in Gines and Benecazón (Seville, Spain).
Explanation: ABC has not published this article

What did you fact-check?: A man with a gas mask at a supermarket in Lugo (Galicia, Spain).
Explanation: The photo was taken in Austria, not Spain.

What did you fact-check?: The wife of a Chinese shop owner in Totana (Murcia, Spain) has coronavirus.
Explanation: The claim is not true.

What did you fact-check?: Authorities should implement temperature tests to travelers from China.
Explanation: There is no evidence the tests are precise enough to detect infections with no fever.

What did you fact-check?: Video of a person infected with coronavirus being detained by the police.
Explanation: This video shows a drill. It was shot 2/21/20 at Henan Tongbai by the police and the emergency response team.

What did you fact-check?: Barcelona’s council issued a notification of a new focus in two neighborhoods.
Explanation: The council denied the claim on its Twitter account.

What did you fact-check?: The wife of a Chinese shop owner in Totana (Murcia, Spain) has coronavirus.
Explanation: The claim is not true.

What did you fact-check?: Jackie Chan is quarantined because of the coronavirus.
Explanation: Jackie Chan states that he was not quarantined.

What did you fact-check?: Clients of a brothel in the Spanish city of Valencia are quarantined after one of their employees tested positive for coronavirus.
Explanation: The claim is not true; it is a humor article.

What did you fact-check?: A “poll finds 38% of Americans say they will not drink Corona beer because of the virus.”
Explanation: The poll was conducted by a PR firm which did not release full details about it.

What did you fact-check?: “The coronavirus has made it to Mississippi and the lady that caught it wasn’t around anybody with it, which means it is airborne. If the wind blows it in your direction, you’ll have it also.”
Explanation: According to the CDC and Mississippi, there are no confirmed COVID-19 cases in the state as of 2/28/20. Researchers believe the disease is spread person to person.

What did you fact-check?: “Every election year has a disease” — SARS in 2004; avian flu in 2008; swine flu in 2010; MERS in 2012; Ebola in 2014 and 2018; Zika in 2016 and the coronavirus in 2020.
Explanation: Most of these diseases were discovered and spread before the election years and were minimally mentioned during campaigns. SARS, avian flu and MERS had virtually no effect on the U.S. during election years.

What did you fact-check?: COVID-19 is just a big flu.
Explanation: It is too early to make this assumption. Statistics show COVID-19 is not a generic virus.

What did you fact-check?: It is best to shave your beard to avoid being infected by the coronavirus.
Explanation: Unless you are in contact with people infected by the virus at work, there is no need to shave your beard.

What did you fact-check?: A man with a gas mask at a supermarket in Lugo (Galicia, Spain).
Explanation: The photo was taken in Austria, not Spain.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus patients in China are caught by officials on a highway.
Explanation: The video shows a mock drill. The China SWAT team in the video is "practicing" how to deal with coronavirus patients.

What did you fact-check?: It is possible to self-diagnose by holding your breath for 10 seconds.
Explanation: There is no medical evidence to support this claim.

What did you fact-check?: Chinese experts warn about a scar in the lung caused by COVID-19. This is more severe than SARS 17 years ago.
Explanation: There is no evidence to support this. A Thai medical doctor insists that not every COVID-19 case damages the lungs.

What did you fact-check?: The German government made a “secret plan” about coronavirus in 2012 that foretold the pandemic.
Explanation: There is no secret plan but a public risk assessment of the German government in 2012 contained a hypothetical epidemic of a fictional coronavirus named Modi-SARS.

What did you fact-check?: The next thing that we will run short of, following masks, is toilet paper.
Explanation: On Feb.28, the industry association released a statement categorically denying rumours that its production capacity fell (in the wake of the novel coronavirus). "Most (of Japan\'s) toilet paper and tissue paper are produced in domestic factories, and neither supplies nor production have been impacted by the novel coronavirus," it said.

What did you fact-check?: Consuming alcohol is an effective measure against COVID-19.
Explanation: The post making this claim contains a doctored screenshot from a CNN broadcast.

What did you fact-check?: Video shows Chinese officials detaining an infected citizen who refused to be tested.
Explanation: The video shows an exercise, not a real event.

What did you fact-check?: A “Lithuanian doctor” gives advice to those potentially infected with the coronavirus.
Explanation: The information is false since instructions to stay at home if infected were not given out by any of the authorities.

What did you fact-check?: Health authorities say shaving a beard protects from COVID-19.
Explanation: " It's a 2017 graphic about how professionals should wear tight-fitting masks."

What did you fact-check?: Airport in Karachi suspends all international arrivals during coronavirus epidemic.
Explanation: " Pakistan's civil aviation authority confirmed international arrivals weren't cancelled at the time; photo corresponds with one that circulated about flights suspended at the airport in March 2019"

What did you fact-check?: Chloroquine cures COVID-19.
Explanation: Chloroquine showed signs is not a cure for COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: Video shows a person infected with coronavirus being detained by the police.
Explanation: " This event is not real, it's a drill. It was shot 2/21/19 at Henan Tongbai by the police and the emergency response team."

What did you fact-check?: A case of coronavirus in the Argentine province of Santiago del Estero was confirmed.
Explanation: There are no confirmed cases of coronavirus in Argentina as of 2/27/20.

What did you fact-check?: A case of coronavirus in the Argentine province of Chaco was confirmed.
Explanation: There are no confirmed cases of coronavirus in Argentina as of 2/27/20.

What did you fact-check?: An Argentinian doctor discovered a vaccine for coronavirus in Spain
Explanation: The statement is false. The man in the attached photo is an actor. The WHO says "there is no vaccine and no specific antiviral medicine to prevent or treat" the coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: The WHO says the coronavirus might be spread by food.
Explanation: The WHO has no evidence that infections from food are possible.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus is not reproducing in warm places.
Explanation: Other coronaviruses have begun to die when the temperature is over 56°C but there are no studies about COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: Bleach and chlorine can be used to prevent the coronavirus.
Explanation: The WHO confirms bleach and other disinfectants might work to kill the coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Iran’s deputy Health Minister
Explanation: Flu death rate in the U.S. is less than 0.1% and the deputy minister’s comparison of flu and COVID-19 is misleading.

What did you fact-check?: The cover of a book titled “Tintin in Wuhan” shows the character standing in an old Chinese market wearing special suits, while people are wearing masks.
Explanation: This is a doctored image made from the frames of two different Tintin books.

What did you fact-check?: French far right leader Marine Le Pen says the EU didn’t act against the outbreak
Explanation: The EU has activated the civil protection mechanism, launched aid programs, mobilized funds for research and called for more international cooperation and coordination.

What did you fact-check?: Lysol products can kill the novel coronavirus.
Explanation: While Lysol products are advertised to kill 99.9% of bacteria and viruses, including coronavirus, the company is referring to previous strains of the virus. There is no known cure for the novel coronavirus strain.

What did you fact-check?: A monkey is been infected with the coronavirus in this photo.
Explanation: The photo is a capture of a video taken at least two months before the first COVID-19 symptoms were experienced.

What did you fact-check?: Lectures have been suspended at the University of Sevilla due to coronavirus.
Explanation: The university stated the document is false.

What did you fact-check?: There is a new case of COVID-19 in Sacedón (Spain).
Explanation: The town office denied the claim.

What did you fact-check?: El Pais said there is a possible case of coronavirus at the hospital Gregorio Marañón in Spain.
Explanation: " El País has not published that article and the typography doesn't match."

What did you fact-check?: An article in El Pais says there is a case of coronavirus at the School of Architecture of Madrid.
Explanation: El País did not publish this article.

What did you fact-check?: First case of coronavirus in Alcalá de Henares (Madrid).
Explanation: One screenshot shows a false article created in an app; the other has not been published by El Mundo newspaper.

What did you fact-check?: A brothel with 86 customers was quarantined after a prostitute tested positive for the coronavirus.
Explanation: This was a satirical comment.

What did you fact-check?: Sevilla’s university has suspended classes because of coronavirus on 2/27/20.
Explanation: The university denied this claim on its Twitter account.

What did you fact-check?: Dr. Gerardo Dovakin found a vaccine against coronavirus.
Explanation: Dovakin is an actor, not a doctor.

What did you fact-check?: Honduras’s first confirmed case traveled to Taiwan earlier, which means there is a severe community transmission in Taiwan.
Explanation: As of 2/27/20, Honduras has no confirmed cases of COVID-19. A Taiwanese traveler had suspected infection, but tested negative.

What did you fact-check?: Taiwan has severe community transmission. Many people have died.
Explanation: As of 2/27/20, there is no evidence indicating the Taiwan government has hidden real COVID-19 figures or information. The Taiwan Central Epidemic Command Center (CECC) has a daily press conference to update the latest confirmed case number and has been transparent.

What did you fact-check?: The outbreak in Taiwan is out of control. President Tsai ordered a corpse burned in front of the presidential office.
Explanation: It is a photo of a self-immolation incident in 2015 in front of the presidential office.

What did you fact-check?: Iranian clerics wear masks after the outbreak.
Explanation: The photo is outdated and manipulated. It was taken at the funeral of Kasem Sulemani.

What did you fact-check?: Drinking water every 10 minutes can send the virus into sthe omach and kill it.
Explanation: " The digestive system cannot stop the respiratory system's work and the course of infection."

What did you fact-check?: The WHO has issued an alert against buying holy colors from China
Explanation: " The WHO hasn't issued an advisory against buying Holi colors from coronavirus-hit China. The claim is fake."

What did you fact-check?: ”America has been vaccinating cattle for coronavirus for years, yet the news tells you it’s new and going to kill you all, so go buy a mask.”
Explanation: " The vaccine for cattle won’t help humans and won't protect against this new form of coronavirus."

What did you fact-check?: “The blood test for coronavirus costs $3,200.”
Explanation: " The CDC isn't charging for coronavirus testing but patients could be stuck with associated costs, such as a trip to the emergency room. In Florida, a man who worried he was infected initially faced a $3,270 bill even though he never received a coronavirus test."

What did you fact-check?: Starting in March, if you travel outside of the United States you won’t be allowed back in the country “due to high risk of the coronavirus.”
Explanation: As of 3/6/20, there is no mandate that states Americans are barred from returning to the U.S. from anywhere overseas.

What did you fact-check?: “‘Akira’ is a 1988 movie about an apocalyptic event taking place months before Tokyo 2020 Olympics, showing the WHO advising Japan to postpone the Olympics because of a pandemic risk.”
Explanation: The movie does not include a pandemic and the WHO is never mentioned.

What did you fact-check?: Iran buries coronavirus victims in Iraq; a video from the Najaf Cemetery.
Explanation: Video shows the burial of Iranians who were infected with COVID-19 in Al-Ahwaz cemetery. The video is from 2019, and depicts the burial of Mohamed Nasri who died of CCHF in Al-Ahwaz in 2019.

What did you fact-check?: Football player Alexis Sanchez is infected with the new coronavirus.
Explanation: Misbar confirmed this statement is false.

What did you fact-check?: Keeping your throat moist will wash the coronavirus down to your stomach where the virus will die.
Explanation: The WHO and Dr. Norberto Francisco, chief of clinical trials and research at the Lung Center of the Philippines, say drinking water will not prevent a coronavirus infection.

What did you fact-check?: Ministry of Economy and Finance in South Korea and pharmaceutical companies had a secret meeting.
Explanation: There was no meeting.

What did you fact-check?: A video accompanying a claim shows bodies being removed from a hospital in Iran during the novel coronavirus pandemic.
Explanation: " The claim is false. The video has circulated since August 2019 and depicts a funeral procession for pilgrims who died during the annual Islamic pilgrimage to Saudi Arabia's Grand Mosque."

What did you fact-check?: Eat herbs, curmin, like people in India, and you will be safe from COVID-19.
Explanation: This claim has no scientific proof.

What did you fact-check?: Each side of protective surgical masks has different functions, indicated by colour, and you should choose the way you wear by whether you are ill or not.
Explanation: This is incorrect. Generally, if they have a coloured side, you should wear your mask with this pointing outward—but always read the manufacturer’s instructions to be sure.

What did you fact-check?: A book published in 1981 said that in 2020 a severe pneumonia-like illness would spread across the world, and calling it “Wuhan-400”.
Explanation: These lines are from two different books

What did you fact-check?: A “letter” from an uncle in Wuhan claims COVID-19 can be cured with hot water.
Explanation: There is no evidence hot water can cure COVID-19, other facts stated in the said letter are also inaccurate.

What did you fact-check?: CDC issued facial hair recommendation for novel coronavirus prevention.
Explanation: Graphic is more than two years old and unrelated to the current outbreak.

What did you fact-check?: There is a confirmed case of coronavirus in a Bogotá hospital.
Explanation: The case was never treated under the suspicion it was coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: You can maintain the alkaline state of the body to avoid contagion.
Explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

What did you fact-check?: Is it useful to close borders to stop the outbreak?
Explanation: French medical experts say closing borders in order to prevent infected people from entering in France is ineffective. Health tests before entering the country have little effect.

What did you fact-check?: Hair Weaves And Lace Front Wigs Made In China Likely To Contain coronavirus.
